• The Department of Defense's (DOD) personal property program is used by personal property shipping office staff to manage household goods moves for all military servicemembers and DOD civilians when they relocate. The military services pay shipment and storage-related costs from their military personnel accounts' permanent change of station budgets. Servicemembers generally work with DOD transportation officials at personal property processing offices to coordinate their moves. These offices provide servicemembers with local points of contact for counseling about their moves and processing paperwork related to shipments of their personal property.

• DOD's personal property program involves a complex process of qualifying carriers, soliciting rates, distributing moves, evaluating moving companies' performance, paying invoices, and settling claims. Among the program's many challenges is ensuring that the moving industry provides adequate year-round capacity, especially during the summer peak moving season. In an effort to test alternative approaches and address some of its challenges, DOD previously evaluated three pilot programs. From those three pilot programs, DOD submitted a report to Congress in 2002 with recommendations to improve the quality of household goods moves for servicemembers.

• DOD developed a new program called Families First to improve the quality of household goods moves for servicemembers, DOD civilian employees, and their families. Families First is a U.S. Transportation Command program that is executed by the Military Surface Deployment and Distribution Command, an Army service component command. The Surface Deployment and Distribution Command determined that it was not feasible to upgrade TOPS to support the goals of Families First for several reasons. TOPS is being phased out because the software is no longer fully supportable and does not meet DOD's technology standards.

• The Families First program has several goals, including improving the quality of service from moving companies, streamlining the claims process, and developing an integrated information management system, known as DPS. DOD designed Families First so that achieving the first two goals of the program relies heavily on completion of the third goal of the program, DPS. DOD identified numerous benefits of the Families First program, including reduced storage costs and greater operational flexibility for moving companies. Two of the program benefits identified by DOD—full replacement value coverage and expanded counseling support through a Web-based information system—are intended to directly benefit servicemembers and promote quality service when moving their personal belongings.

• Tobacco is a high-value, pesticide-intensive crop, ranking sixth in pesticide application per acre in the United States. It is grown in 16 states, with Kentucky and North Carolina producing about two-thirds of all domestic tobacco. Tobacco is also grown in over 100 countries, with the United States being the second-largest producer of cigarettes in the world. Most tobacco grown in the United States is used to manufacture cigarettes.

• The tobacco industry in the United States exports tobacco to Japan and Western Europe and imports tobacco from countries such as Brazil, Argentina, Malawi, and Thailand. The United States is also a significant producer of chewing tobacco, snuff, cigars, and pipe tobacco. Tobacco types are defined by characteristics such as curing methods, color, size, and thickness of the leaves. Different types of tobacco are used in various tobacco products.

• Pesticides play a significant role in increasing production of tobacco, but exposure to pesticides can harm humans. The potential for harm is related to both the amount of a substance a person is exposed to and the toxicity of the chemical. EPA reviews pesticides to ensure they meet contemporary health and safety standards and that their risks are mitigated. Manufacturers of older pesticides must provide EPA with substantially the same toxicity, chemistry, and other data as are now required to register a new pesticide.

• EPA's health risk assessments focus on the potential cancer and noncancer health risks associated with short-term, intermediate-, and long-term exposures to pesticides from primary exposure routes. Noncancer health risks assessed include risk of birth defects, reproductive impairments, damage to genetic material, and interference with the body's endocrine system. EPA's health risk assessments are subject to numerous reviews by various committees. The agency's evaluations of these studies are critical to the assessment process.

• EPA requires pesticide manufacturers to provide most of the studies it considers in assessing the health risks of pesticides, and the agency's evaluations of these studies are critical to the assessment process. EPA officials were generally able to provide copies of the studies and evaluations requested, but documentation of the agency's evaluation of the quality of the residue studies was inconsistent. For eight of the pesticides, EPA officials were unable to provide their evaluations of the validity and reliability of residue data. EPA officials noted that each pesticide registration could consist of 100 or more studies from pesticide manufacturers.

• The USDA tests imported and domestic tobacco to ensure that residues do not exceed the maximum allowable concentrations established by the agency. The testing program focuses on 20 pesticides not approved for use on tobacco in the United States

• User fees are a financing approach for federal programs or activities, where costs are assigned to identifiable users of those programs and activities. This approach is based on the principle that users should pay for the benefits they receive from a program.

• User fees can be in the form of user fees, user charges, or excise taxes on certain products, and they are often used to fund programs that benefit identifiable users. Examples of user fees include those imposed on motor fuels, tires, and heavy vehicles that accrue to the Highway Trust Fund.

• The boundaries between fees and taxes are not always clear, and the trade-offs among design elements can be relevant to both. A user fee is related to some voluntary transaction or request for government goods or services above and beyond what is normally available to the public.

• The Supreme Court has ruled that a tax is "an enforced contribution to provide for the support of government," and the legal distinction between a "fee" and a "tax" can be complicated and depends largely on the context of the particular assessment. Whether a particular assessment is statutorily referred to as a tax or a fee is never legally determinative.

• Fees vary in the degree to which they can be considered truly voluntary because the availability of reasonable substitutes varies. For example, to enter certain national parks, one must pay an entrance fee, but people who want to operate radio stations have no similarly close alternative and must obtain a license from the Federal Communications Commission.

• Agencies derive their authority to charge fees either from the Independent Offices Appropriation Act of 1952 (IOAA) or from specific statutory authority. IOAA provides broad authority to assess user fees or charges on identifiable beneficiaries by administrative regulation.

• The beneficiary-pays principle is a useful guideline for assigning costs, determining a program's beneficiaries and the extent to which a program benefits users, the general public, or both. This principle can promote equity by assigning costs to those who both use and benefit from the services.

• Fees can be practical, equitable, and efficient only when the users can be identified and charged for the service or program. Sometimes, however, it may be difficult to identify specific users or to collect fees from them, making it difficult to follow the beneficiary-pays principle.

• The primary challenge in determining when and how to collect a fee is striking a balance between ensuring compliance and minimizing administrative costs. Fees can be collected at the point of sale before the service is provided, at the point of service, or after the service has been provided.

<summary>

* The Department of Defense (DOD) establishes a standard price per barrel for fuel, which is used to calculate the budget estimates for fuel costs. The standard price is set annually by the Office of the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller) in coordination with the Defense Logistics Agency (DLA).
* The standard price is based on three components: crude oil price, refinement markup, and nonproduct costs. The crude oil price is forecasted by the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) and is used as the baseline for setting the standard price.
* The refinement markup is estimated based on the historical price relationship between crude oil and refined product prices. DOD has increased the refinement markup from 30% to 50% of the WTI price to account for the divergence between WTI and other crude oil pricing benchmarks.
* The nonproduct costs include overhead, transportation, and storage costs, as well as product losses and cost recovery adjustments. DOD has not documented its rationale for selecting WTI as the crude oil benchmark, despite OMB providing more than WTI crude oil forecasts in its economic assumptions.
* The standard price is used to calculate the budget estimates for fuel costs, which are then used to determine the funding needs for the military services. The military services use the standard price and their estimated fuel requirements to determine their fuel costs.
* DOD has faced challenges in setting a standard price that closely approximates its actual fuel costs, with actual prices differing from estimates by an average of 74% from 2009 to 2013. The differences between estimated and actual fuel costs have been driven by fluctuations in fuel prices and differences between estimated and actual fuel consumption.
* DOD has taken actions to manage the effect of differences between estimated and actual fuel costs, including transferring funds into and out of the Defense-wide Working Capital Fund and adjusting the standard price. The Defense-wide Working Capital Fund is intended to provide DOD with the flexibility to absorb some fluctuation in fuel prices.
* The GAO recommends that the Secretary of Defense direct the Office of the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller) to reevaluate the approach for estimating the components of the standard price and document its assumptions, including providing a detailed rationale for how it estimates each of these components. DOD has partially concurred with the recommendation, stating that it is continually evaluating methods to better estimate the price of fuel.

</summary>

<summary>

• The current fiscal environment requires agencies to separate wants from needs to ensure that programs and investments provide the best return within fiscal constraints. Agency budgets may not be fully linked to strategic goals and may not adequately consider likely agencywide resource limitations. Agencies too often pursue their individual needs rather than collective needs. This can lead to poor acquisition outcomes and waste of investments.

• Agencies need to translate their needs into appropriate, executable programs and set realistic system requirements. They also need to ensure that programs proceed through the acquisition process based on having requisite knowledge and that programs are funded adequately. However, too often we see failure in one or more of these key dimensions. This can result in overpromising and underdelivering in the acquisition of major systems.

• The government faces serious acquisition workforce challenges, including size, skills, and knowledge, and succession planning. Key program staff rotate too frequently, promoting myopia and reducing accountability. The revolving door between industry and agencies presents potential conflicts of interest. This can lead to inadequate oversight and little or no accountability for recurring and systemic problems.

• The acquisition workforce's workload and complexity of responsibilities have been increasing without adequate agency attention to the workforce's size, skills, and knowledge, and succession planning. This situation is made all the more challenging by the increasing use of contractors to support program operations. Agencies lack good data on their workforces, and the size of the workforce has declined while the size of government expenditures for goods and services has risen significantly. This represents a major challenge to the current workforce.

• The government needs to engage in a fundamental and comprehensive re-examination of the federal government's overall approach to contracting. This includes when and on what basis the government should contract. Agencies will need to be realistic in their requirements and technologies before investing significant funds in programs. They must also strike a better balance among expediency, best value, and oversight when entering into contracts for goods and services.

• The government should have zero tolerance for waste and mismanagement in times of surplus or deficit. However, much can and should be done to minimize it. The government has made numerous specific recommendations to DOD and other agencies on how to address these systemic acquisition challenges. Where agencies are responding to these recommendations, we are seeing some improvements in their acquisition management.

• The government's current financial condition and long-term fiscal outlook require it to seek the best return it can on its investment in goods and services. The federal government needs to engage in a fundamental re-examination of the federal government's overall approach to contracting. This includes when

<summary>

* The Department of Defense's (DOD) procurement process involves acquiring supplies and services from nonfederal sources and administering related contractual instruments. The Standard Procurement System (SPS) was initiated in 1994 to acquire and deploy a single automated system for contract management-related functions. SPS was intended to standardize procurement business practices and data elements throughout DOD.
* The SPS program has faced significant challenges, including software deficiencies, user dissatisfaction, and delays in meeting milestones. The program has also been criticized for its lack of economic justification and failure to meet key commitments. The DOD Office of the Inspector General has issued several reports critical of SPS.
* The SPS program has not met its cost, schedule, and performance commitments, and the system has not produced the expected benefits. The program has also been plagued by software problems, including instability and frequent downtime. The system's functionality has not met user needs, and users have been forced to develop workarounds.
* The SPS program has not been economically justified, and the economic analyses prepared for the program have been criticized for their reliability. The analyses have not reflected changes in the program's scope and schedule, and they have not included all relevant costs. The program's net present value has been calculated to be negative.
* The DOD has not followed best practices for investment management, including incremental investment management. The program has not been divided into smaller, more manageable components, and the costs and benefits of each component have not been separately justified. The program has not been monitored for progress against cost, schedule, and performance commitments.
* The GAO has recommended that the Secretary of Defense direct the Assistant Secretary of Defense for Command, Control, Communications, and Intelligence to clarify organizational accountability and responsibility for measuring SPS progress against commitments. The GAO has also recommended that investment in each new release of SPS be conditional upon validating that already implemented releases are producing benefits that exceed costs. The GAO has further recommended that no further decisions to invest in SPS be made without validation results.
* The DOD has disagreed with the GAO's recommendations, citing concerns about the efficiency and cost of incremental investment management. However, the GAO has argued that incremental investment management is a best practice and is required by the Clinger-Cohen Act of 1996 and OMB guidance. The GAO has also pointed out that the economic analysis used to justify SPS is not reliable and does not reflect all relevant costs and benefits.

<summary>

* *The U.S. Citizenship and Immigration Services (USCIS) is responsible for processing millions of immigration benefit applications each year, determining eligibility, and detecting suspicious information for fraud investigation.* USCIS processes applications for about 50 types of immigration benefits and had a staff of about 3,000 permanent adjudicators in 2005.

* *In fiscal year 2005, USCIS received about 6.3 million applications and adjudicated about 7.5 million applications.* The agency's budget for 2005 was just under $1.8 billion, with $1.6 billion from service fees and $160 million from congressionally appropriated funds.

* *USCIS has a backlog of several million applications and has developed a plan to eliminate it by the end of fiscal year 2006.* The agency reported that it would have to increase production by about 20 percent to achieve its goal of adjudicating all applications within 6 months or less by the end of fiscal year 2005.

* *The immigration services and enforcement functions of the former INS transitioned to different organizations within DHS in 2003.* USCIS assumed the immigration benefit functions, and ICE assumed INS's investigative and detention and removal of aliens functions.

* *The Office of the Citizenship and Immigration Services Ombudsman was created by the Homeland Security Act of 2002.* The ombudsman's primary function is to assist individuals and employers in resolving problems with USCIS and identify areas where individuals and employers have problems dealing with USCIS.

* *The Department of State is responsible for approving and issuing visas allowing aliens to travel to the United States.* The Department of Labor's Division of Foreign Labor Certification provides national leadership and policy guidance for foreign workers seeking admission to the United States for employment.

* *USCIS has taken some important steps to detect immigration benefit fraud, including establishing an internal unit to address immigration benefit fraud and conducting a series of fraud assessments.* However, USCIS has not applied some aspects of internal control standards and fraud control best practices that could further enhance its ability to detect fraud.

* *The Standards for Internal Control in the Federal Government provide an overall framework to identify and address fraud, waste, abuse, and mismanagement.* Implementing good internal control activities and establishing a positive control environment is central to an agency's efforts to detect and deter immigration benefit fraud.

* *USCIS lacks a comprehensive approach for managing risk, a monitoring mechanism to ensure that knowledge arising from routine operations informs the assessment of policies

<summary>

• The objective of the audit was to assess the performance of the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) during the 1994 filing season, focusing on its ability to process income tax returns and refunds accurately and efficiently, and to provide taxpayers with access to forms, information, and electronic filing methods. The audit was conducted from January to August 1994, in accordance with generally accepted government auditing standards. The audit team reviewed various data and reports, including those on refund accuracy and timeliness, and interviewed IRS officials to gather information. The audit aimed to identify areas of improvement and provide recommendations for the IRS.

• The audit found that the IRS generally performed well during the 1994 filing season, with some positive aspects, such as an increase in the number of individual income tax returns filed and a decrease in the number of errors in processing returns. However, there were also some problems, including a leading source of errors by taxpayers and tax practitioners in preparing returns, which contributed to the IRS' error resolution workload. The audit also found that the number of fraudulent refund claims identified by the IRS continued to grow at a troubling pace. The IRS had exceeded its accuracy and timeliness goals for processing refunds and had taken positive steps to improve its processing of tax receipts.

• The audit noted that the IRS had revised its projection model for the 1994 filing season, dropping the expected number of filings from 117.5 million to 114.5 million, due to an unexpected drop in individual income tax return filings in 1993. The audit did not review or test the assumptions used to revise the projection model, and therefore could not comment on the reasonableness of the adjustment. The audit found that the overall number of individual filers had not significantly increased, but taxpayer use of alternative filing methods had generally increased in 1994. The IRS offered three types of filing alternatives to the traditional paper return: electronic, TeleFile, and 1040PC.

• The audit found that the IRS' computer systems generally performed well during the 1994 filing season, with some intermittent problems causing minor delays. The audit noted that the Automated Underreporter System at one service center caused a problem that led to the layoff of 270 temporary employees for about a week. The IRS had some systems problems that affected taxpayers, including a problem that caused tax returns to not be processed on time. The audit found that the IRS had exceeded its accuracy and timeliness goals for processing refunds.

• The audit noted that the Earned Income Credit (EIC)

<summary>

* The Medicaid program was established in 1965 as a jointly funded federal-state program providing medical assistance to qualified low-income persons. Each state designs and administers its own Medicaid program, subject to federal requirements for eligibility, services covered, and provider payments. States decide whether to cover optional services and how much to reimburse providers for a particular service.
* In recent years, Medicaid costs have escalated, and some states have sought to move some or most of their Medicaid population into a capitated managed care system. However, certain provisions of the Medicaid law inhibit states' use of managed care. States may obtain waivers of these provisions from HCFA under the authority of section 1115 of the Social Security Act.
* Section 1115 of the act offers HCFA the authority to waive a broad range of Medicaid requirements for state demonstration projects. In granting a waiver, HCFA requires the applying state to demonstrate that its proposal is budget neutral. Until recently, budget neutrality was expected to be achieved in each year of the demonstration.
* Tennessee became the first state to move its Medicaid program enrollees to a statewide demonstration project, known as TennCare, in January 1994. TennCare was designed to use a capitated managed care system to expand coverage to the uninsured population and to control total program and state costs. The state-federal sharing arrangements of the financing plan tend to favor the state.
* The TennCare waiver agreement includes an overall available federal funding limit for the 5-year waiver period and sets interim limits on the availability of federal funding. The federal spending limits apply to the total TennCare program expenditures, including Medicaid expenditures for services not covered under capitated payments. For the 5-year TennCare waiver period, the federal government will provide no more than $12.165 billion.
* The state benefits from federal funding provided to state mental hospitals for expanded TennCare coverage, some of which is not covered under Medicaid rules. Most significantly, Medicaid does not cover persons between the ages of 21 and 65 in state mental hospitals. TennCare allows short-term coverage of this population and reimburses mental hospitals directly for the actual costs of such services.
* The state has a tax of 2 percent on payments made to HMOs and 1.75 percent on payments to PPOs. The tax on HMOs existed before TennCare, and a tax on accident and health insurers that existed before TennCare was extended to include PPOs. Total capitation tax payments for 1994 were approximately $24 million.

<summary>
* The Medicare subvention demonstration, which allowed older military retirees to enroll in a DOD-run managed care organization called Senior Prime, resulted in greater access to care and improved enrollee satisfaction, but also raised DOD's costs due to higher utilization of services.
* The demonstration's payment rules, which required DOD to maintain its level of effort in providing care to older retirees, resulted in Medicare owing DOD nothing for care provided in 1999, and DOD's costs for Senior Prime enrollees were over 80 percent higher than the Senior Prime capitation rate.
</summary>

<summary>
• The worker-profiling initiative was introduced in the 1990s to identify unemployment claimants who are most likely to exhaust benefits and provide them with reemployment services. The initiative requires states to use statistical models or characteristic screens to identify claimants who are likely to exhaust benefits and refer them to reemployment services.
• The effectiveness of the worker-profiling initiative is not well understood, as research studies have found mixed results, and Labor's data collection efforts have been limited by reliability issues. Despite this, some studies have found that profiling and referral to services can lead to a reduction in claimants' duration on UI, a reduction in the amount of UI benefits paid out, and an increase in subsequent employment earnings.
• To improve the worker-profiling initiative, the Secretary of Labor is recommended to reevaluate the agency's data collection efforts, ensure the accuracy of state profiling models, encourage states to adhere to Labor's vision for in-depth reemployment services, and evaluate the impact of the worker-profiling program on the reemployment of UI recipients.

<summary>
• The federal public health response to emerging drug use problems, such as the crack epidemic in the 1980s, has been hindered by limitations in the drug detection system, including gaps in populations surveyed, methodological limitations, and the lack of timely analysis and dissemination of data.
• To improve the nation's drug use detection and response capability, the Director of ONDCP is recommended to implement changes to improve the completeness, accuracy, and overall usefulness of data generated by the nation's drug data collection mechanisms and develop a defined strategy for determining the timing, magnitude, and nature of actions needed to respond to potential drug crises or epidemics.
</summary>

<summary>
* The National Transportation Safety Board (NTSB) has made significant progress in implementing leading management practices in areas such as communication, strategic planning, IT, and financial management. NTSB has fully implemented three of the 15 management recommendations made by the Government Accountability Office (GAO) in 2006 and 2008.
* NTSB has also made progress in implementing GAO recommendations on human capital management, including developing a human capital plan and providing diversity training to senior managers. However, the agency's workforce demographics still present a challenge to increasing diversity in senior management.
* NTSB has fully implemented GAO recommendations on investigating accidents, including developing transparent policies for selecting which accidents to investigate. The agency has also made progress in implementing recommendations on increasing the use of safety studies, but still has not completed any safety studies since 2006.
* NTSB has made significant progress in increasing the use of the Training Center, including subleasing office space and increasing revenues from course fees and rents. The agency has also reduced personnel expenses related to the Training Center and increased other agencies' use of the center's classroom space.
* NTSB has proposed changes to its authorizing legislation, including the statutory authority to investigate incidents in addition to accidents, and reducing requirements for investigating rail and maritime accidents. The proposed changes would give the agency more discretion in selecting investigations and would affect all modes of transportation.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Clean Air Act, a comprehensive federal law, was passed in 1963 to regulate air pollution from stationary and mobile sources, and has been substantially overhauled in 1970, 1977, and 1990 to improve and protect the nation's air quality.
• The Act requires EPA to establish national ambient air quality standards for pollutants at levels necessary to protect public health and welfare, and has set standards for ozone, carbon monoxide, particulate matter, sulfur oxides, nitrogen dioxide, and lead.
• EPA has completed most of the 452 actions required by the 1990 amendments related to Titles I, III, and IV, but missed deadlines for many requirements, with 256 of the 338 requirements with statutory deadlines completed late.
• The Clean Air Act requires states to develop implementation plans to achieve and maintain compliance with national standards, and EPA must review and approve these plans, with oversight from EPA.
• EPA has made progress in reducing emissions of the six principal air pollutants, with total emissions dropping by 54 percent between 1970 and 2004, but large numbers of Americans continue to live in communities where pollution sometimes exceeds federal air quality standards.
• The agency has applied the cap-and-trade model to several pollutants since 2000, but the effectiveness of this approach for hazardous air pollutants such as mercury is unclear, particularly in light of a lawsuit challenging EPA's March 2005 rule on mercury emissions.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Federal Reserve Act established the Federal Reserve as an independent agency with a decentralized structure to ensure that monetary policy decisions would be based on a broad economic perspective from all regions of the country. The Federal Reserve operates in a unique public and private structure, consisting of the Board of Governors, the 12 Reserve Banks, and FOMC. The Board of Governors is an independent regulatory federal agency located in Washington, D.C., and has broad interest in monitoring and promoting the stability of financial markets.
• The Reserve Banks are not federal agencies, but rather federally chartered corporations with a board of directors and member banks that are stockholders. The Reserve Banks derive income from various sources, maintain surplus accounts, and remit earnings in excess of expenses to Treasury. Modifying the Reserve Bank stock ownership requirement could have a number of implications, including disrupting the Federal Reserve's public and private balance, and diminishing Reserve Bank autonomy and financial independence.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Government Performance and Results Act (GPRA) aims to shift the focus of government decision-making from activities and processes to results and outcomes achieved by federal programs. GPRA requires federal agencies to provide new and valuable information on their plans, goals, and strategies. Annual performance plans are to clearly inform Congress and the public of performance goals, measures, strategies, and resources required to achieve these goals. These plans provide a direct linkage between an agency's longer-term goals and mission and day-to-day activities.
* The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has implemented GPRA and provided information on its plans, goals, and strategies. EPA has made progress in achieving its long-term goal of safe and healthy air in communities. The agency has improved air quality in areas that do not meet the National Ambient Air Quality Standards (NAAQS) established by EPA. EPA's strategy for achieving its goal of improving air quality involves working with states, tribes, and local governments to achieve compliance with NAAQS.
* EPA has also made progress in ensuring that water is safe for drinking. The agency has achieved its goal of having 91 percent of the population served by community drinking water systems receiving drinking water that meets all health-based standards. EPA's strategy for ensuring safe drinking water involves several approaches, including issuing standards for acceptable levels of contaminants in drinking water. The agency relies heavily on actions by the states to implement programs to help ensure that drinking water systems comply with regulations.
* EPA's performance report acknowledges data limitations with the Aerometric Information Retrieval System for reporting NAAQS progress. The report states that data demonstrating improvement in national ambient air quality standards may be limited by inaccuracies due to imprecise measurement and recording. EPA has quality assurance and control procedures to ensure accurate data gathering and reporting. The agency's reported progress for its annual performance goal related to toxic air pollutant emissions relies on calculations and estimates.
* EPA's fiscal year 2000 performance report made several improvements from the prior year, including discussing prior fiscal year's performance and actions taken by other organizations to attain goals. The report also identified actions taken to validate data on performance and presented tables of results by individual strategic goal. EPA's performance plan for fiscal year 2002 reflects numerous changes to the performance goals and related objectives from the 2001 performance plan. The agency has maintained the titles of goals for the key outcomes reviewed, but the definition of the safe food goal was changed in the fiscal year 2002 plan.
* EPA's performance report discusses the agency's progress in

<summary>
• The Master Address File (MAF) is a data file containing a list of all known living quarters in the United States and Puerto Rico, used to support the decennial census and other demographic surveys. The MAF contains address information, census geographic location codes, and source and history data.
• The MAF is updated through a complete address canvassing, which verifies existing addresses and adds new ones, but this process is costly. The Bureau is researching the feasibility of conducting targeted address canvassing, verifying addresses in select areas that require updates.
• The Bureau plans to increase its reliance on other sources of updates, including U.S. Postal Service files, commercial database files, and input from state and local governments. The GSS-I is working to allow government agencies to share and update their address lists with the Bureau throughout the decade.
• The life cycle for 2020 Census preparation is divided into five phases, with the early research and testing phase through fiscal year 2015 focused on developing a proposal for conducting targeted address canvassing. The Bureau plans to complete decisions about preliminary operational designs by the end of the early research and testing phase.
• The Bureau relies on schedules to monitor progress and manage risks in preparing and implementing a successful decennial census. Effective scheduling is critical for ensuring that the Bureau adheres to a timeline that meets legally mandated deadlines.
• The Bureau's 2020 Research and Testing and GSS-I schedules exhibit some characteristics of a reliable schedule, but important weaknesses remain. The schedules substantially met one of the four characteristics (controlled) and minimally or partially met the other three characteristics (comprehensive, well constructed, and credible).
• The Bureau is using a work breakdown structure to guide the activities of the 2020 Research and Testing and GSS-I schedules, but not all activities listed are included in the schedules. The Bureau has not yet produced a timeline for all enterprise activities, and staff have not received training in the software they are using for scheduling.
• The Bureau's schedules have shortcomings with integration into management reporting and the ability to automatically change as activities within the schedule change. The Bureau has not conducted a quantitative risk analysis on its schedule, which would help illustrate the impact of risks on the schedule and how that would affect the Bureau's ability to meet milestones.
• The Bureau has put in place a framework to support collaborative efforts following leading practices, including memorandums of understanding and charters, but has not taken advantage of some opportunities to use its schedules to reinforce roles or clarify responsibilities. The Secretary of Commerce

<summary>

* The Department of Defense (DOD) launched the Corporate Information Management (CIM) initiative in 1989 to improve business practices and make better use of information technology. The initiative aimed to eliminate duplicative information systems and improve business processes across seven administrative areas. CIM's primary objective is to significantly improve business processes through techniques such as business process reengineering and continuous process improvements.
* The CIM initiative has undergone significant changes since its inception, with its scope broadening to include all DOD functional areas. The initiative's focus has shifted from eliminating separate service systems to selecting and implementing migration systems for materiel management and depot maintenance. DOD believes that selecting migration systems is necessary to achieve quick cost savings and form a foundation for major business process improvements.
* The Joint Logistics System Center (JLSC) was established to oversee the implementation of CIM in the logistics functions of materiel management and depot maintenance. JLSC's initial strategy focused on implementing near-term initiatives, but it was redirected to select and implement migration systems. JLSC has selected 32 migration systems for materiel management and depot maintenance, which are expected to save the services and DLA billions of dollars over the next decade.
* Despite the progress made by JLSC, the CIM initiative faces several impediments, including a lack of acceptance by DOD functional and technical managers. The initiative's management strategy has been criticized for being too focused on information technology, rather than business process reengineering. DOD officials have acknowledged the need to change the initiative's management strategy and provide more training to employees.
* To overcome the fundamental weaknesses in the management of the CIM initiative, we recommend that the Secretary take several actions, including revising the CIM management strategy, training DOD employees, and changing the name of the initiative. The Secretary should also ensure that functional managers actively participate and lead efforts to reengineer DOD's business processes under the CIM initiative. By taking these actions, DOD can overcome the cultural barriers impeding the initiative and achieve its goals of improving business operations and reducing costs.</summary>

<summary>
* The 1992 congressional testimony identified three ways thieves turn stolen cars into money: by dismantling and selling parts at a "chop shop," obtaining a valid title and selling the car, or exporting the vehicle for sale abroad. The 1992 Act aimed to address these issues by establishing a task force, a national motor vehicle title information system, and a parts marking program.
* The task force recommended uniform definitions for terms such as salvage vehicles and uniform methods for titling vehicles, but the recommendations were not fully implemented. The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA) prepared legislation to address the task force's recommendations, but it was not introduced in Congress.
* The National Stolen Passenger Motor Vehicle Information System (NSPMVIS) was established to contain vehicle identification numbers and other related data for stolen passenger motor vehicles and parts, but its implementation was delayed due to funding and technical issues. The system was eventually piloted in Texas and Illinois, but its effectiveness was limited by the lack of funding and resources.
</summary>

<summary>
* The distribution of and payment for prescription drugs involves interactions among multiple entities, including drug wholesalers, independent pharmacies, Pharmacy Service Administrative Organizations (PSAOs), and third-party payers and their Pharmacy Benefit Managers (PBMs).
* PSAOs provide a range of services to independent pharmacies, including negotiating contractual agreements, providing communication and help-desk services, and assisting with payment and reconciliation, which can help pharmacies achieve administrative efficiencies and reduce costs.
* The majority of PSAOs in operation in 2011 or 2012 were owned by wholesalers and independent pharmacy cooperatives, and while most PSAO owners do not require their member pharmacies to use services from their primary line of business, member pharmacies may choose to do so and contract and pay for PSAO and other services separately.
</summary>

<summary>

• The Department of Defense (DOD) relies on research laboratories, industry, and academia to develop new technologies, but historically, it has experienced problems in bringing technologies out of the lab environment and into real use. DOD has established various technology transition programs to address these challenges, including the Advanced Concept Technology Demonstration (ACTD) program, the Foreign Comparative Testing (FCT) Program, and the Dual Use Science and Technology program. These programs aim to speed up the transition of technologies from the laboratory to the field.

• The Technology Transition Initiative (TTI), the Defense Acquisition Challenge Program (DACP), and the Quick Reaction Fund are three new transition programs established to address the challenges of technology transition. The TTI focuses on speeding the transition of technologies developed by DOD's S&T programs into acquisition programs, while the DACP focuses on introducing innovative and cost-saving technologies developed inside and outside DOD. The Quick Reaction Fund is focused on field testing technology prototypes.

• The three transition programs have reported benefits, including improvements to performance, affordability, manufacturability, and operational capability for the warfighter. However, it is too early to determine the impact of these programs on technology transition, and only a few projects have been completed. The programs have limited performance measures to gauge success and track return on investment over time.

• The DACP has a fairly robust selection process, relying on internet-based tools to communicate its goals and announce its selection process. The program also solicits technical experts from inside and outside DOD to assess potential benefits and risks. However, the sheer number of proposals has tended to overwhelm DACP staff and slowed down the selection process.

• The TTI program also has a fairly rigorous selection process, with specific criteria for selection, including technology readiness. However, the program has been taking steps to strengthen its ability to reach out to the S&T community. The TTI does not confirm Technology Readiness Levels (TRLs), which can be a valuable decision-making tool.

• The Quick Reaction Fund selection process was much less structured and disciplined than DACP and TTI, but the program is now taking steps to strengthen selection processes. The program experienced problems related to selection, including significant gaps in knowledge about technology readiness. The program manager is currently taking steps to improve the management and oversight of projects.

• The GAO recommends that the Secretary of Defense take five actions to optimize DOD's growing investment in the TTI, DACP, and Quick Reaction Fund. The recommendations include developing data and measures to support assessments of

<summary>
• The Government Accountability Office (GAO) conducted an undercover investigation to test the security of radioactive materials at the US borders. The investigation involved producing counterfeit documents, including NRC documents and a bill of lading, to support the investigators' reason for possessing radioactive sources. The investigators used commercial software to produce the counterfeit documents.
• The GAO investigators purchased radioactive sources and containers from a commercial supplier over the phone, without being asked to provide an NRC document. The supplier did not exercise due diligence in determining the buyer's legitimate use for the radioactive sources. The investigators were able to purchase the radioactive sources without being questioned.
• The investigators transported two containers of radioactive sources into the US through an official port of entry in Washington, D.C. They presented a counterfeit bill of lading and a counterfeit NRC document to the CBP inspector. The CBP inspector did not question the validity of the documents.
• The CBP inspector used a handheld Radiation Isotope Identifier Device (RIID) to examine the vehicle, but did not detect the presence of radioactive sources. The investigators were then allowed to enter the US without further inspection. The CBP inspector made copies of the investigators' drivers' licenses.
• The investigators also transported radioactive sources into the US through an official port of entry at the southern border. They presented a counterfeit bill of lading and a counterfeit NRC document to the CBP inspector. The CBP inspector did not question the validity of the documents.
• The CBP inspector used a RIID to scan the outside of the vehicle and detected the presence of radioactive sources. The investigators were then directed to park in a secondary inspection zone for further inspection. The CBP inspector asked for paperwork authorizing the transportation of the equipment.
• The GAO investigators briefed CBP officials about the results of their border crossing tests and suggested ways to verify the authenticity of NRC materials documents. CBP officials agreed to work with the NRC and CBP's Laboratories and Scientific Services to address the issue. The NRC officials disagreed with the amount of radioactive material needed to produce a dirty bomb.
• The GAO investigators believe that the amount of radioactive sources they were able to transport into the US would be sufficient to produce two dirty bombs. They also believe that the NRC should address the issue of counterfeit documents and the potential problems of counterfeiting. The NRC officials acknowledged the potential problems and are working to resolve them.
</summary>

<summary>
* The U.S.-Oman Free Trade Agreement (FTA) was signed on January 19, 2006, and aims to promote economic growth and trade between the two countries, with provisions for tariff reductions, market access, and labor and environmental protections.
* The agreement has been met with both support and criticism, with some arguing that it does not adequately address labor and environmental concerns, while others see it as a step towards greater economic cooperation and stability in the Middle East.
</summary>

<summary>

* The Department of Defense (DOD) created the Defense Finance and Accounting Service (DFAS) in 1991 to standardize DOD finance and accounting policies, procedures, and systems. Before 1991, the military services maintained separate finance and accounting operations that were duplicative and inefficient. DFAS was formed by consolidating the large finance and accounting centers that belonged to the military services and the Defense Logistics Agency. The establishment of DFAS was the first step taken by DOD to fundamentally reform finance and accounting operations.
* DFAS is responsible for performing most of the finance and accounting operations at consolidated sites rather than at local bases and installations. This has allowed it to reduce the number of locations and personnel needed to perform these operations and to begin standardizing its accounting systems and processes. DFAS has developed a new concept of operations that involves performing most of its finance and accounting operations at consolidated sites. The military services continue to perform their remaining activities at most of the 332 installations.
* DFAS is responsible for paying the salaries of 826,000 civilians and about 3 million military personnel, processing payments to about 2 million retirees and annuitants, and making payments to contractors for goods and services. DFAS also collects debts owed to DOD, including debts from military and civilian personnel and contractors. The military services perform debt management activities at each of their installations, but DFAS is responsible for collecting debts owed by contractors. DFAS updates its accounting records to reflect any debt collection or write-off.
* DOD's finance and accounting infrastructure includes 21 operating locations and 5 centers, with a total of 23,500 employees. The military services estimate that they have about 17,300 finance and accounting personnel. DFAS has reduced the number of finance and accounting systems used throughout DOD from 324 to 217 since 1991. The military services continue to operate hundreds of feeder systems for which DFAS has no responsibility.

<summary>

* The Girls Study Group was established in 2004 by OJJDP to identify effective or promising programs for preventing and reducing girls' delinquency. The group reviewed over 1,000 documents and identified 61 programs that specifically targeted girls' delinquency. The group assessed the methodological quality of the studies using the What Works criteria developed by DOJ's Office of Justice Programs. The results of the group's assessment are discussed in the following sections.
* The Study Group's composition was initially imbalanced in favor of academic researchers, but OJJDP officials took steps to address this issue by adding a second practitioner as a member and involving two other practitioners in study group activities. The group plans to issue a final report on all of its activities by spring 2010. The Study Group found that few girls' delinquency programs had been studied and that the available studies lacked conclusive evidence of effective programs. OJJDP plans to provide technical assistance to help programs be better prepared for evaluations of their effectiveness.
* The Study Group reported that among other things, there is a need for additional, methodologically rigorous evaluations of girls' delinquency programs; training and technical assistance to help programs prepare for evaluations; and funding to support girls' delinquency programs found to be promising. OJJDP officials stated that they plan to work with the group and use the remaining funding from the effort to provide a technical assistance workshop by the end of October 2009. The workshop is intended to help approximately 10 girls' delinquency programs prepare for evaluation. OJJDP also plans to issue a solicitation in fiscal year 2010 for funding to support evaluations of girls' delinquency programs.
* OJJDP has not developed a plan that is documented, is shared with key stakeholders, and includes specific funding requirements and commitments and time frames for meeting its girls' delinquency goals. Standard practices for program and project management state that specific desired outcomes or results should be conceptualized, defined, and documented in the planning process. Developing a plan for girls' delinquency would help OJJDP to demonstrate leadership to the girls' delinquency field by clearly articulating the actions it intends to take to meet its goals. OJJDP is in the process of developing a plan for its juvenile justice programs, but the office is taking steps to address its girls' delinquency goals.

<summary>
* The Pacific Islands region is a strategically important area that encompasses U.S. Pacific territories, with the United States, Australia, and New Zealand being key players in the region, while China has also become a significant diplomatic and economic force.
* The region faces various challenges, including climate change, natural disasters, and economic development, with the United States providing foreign assistance and support to Pacific Island countries through various programs and initiatives.
</summary>

<summary>
• China's economy is heavily dependent on global trade and investment flows, with exports contributing to one-third of its GDP growth in 2007. The country's reliance on trade and foreign direct investment (FDI) has made it vulnerable to the global economic slowdown.
• China's exposure to the global financial crisis is unclear, but its government entities, such as state banks and state-owned enterprises, may have been more exposed to troubled U.S. mortgage securities. The Chinese government has not released detailed information on the holdings of its financial entities.
• China has taken steps to respond to the global financial crisis, including cutting interest rates, boosting bank lending, and implementing a stimulus package worth 4 trillion yuan ($586 billion). The stimulus package aims to promote economic growth, increase consumer spending, and rebalance the economy.
• China's current economic recovery is uncertain, with many analysts questioning the sustainability of the growth due to the country's reliance on large-scale bank lending and infrastructure spending. The government's stimulus policies may slow efforts to further reform the economy, especially in regards to state-owned enterprises and the banking system.
</summary>

<summary>
• Concerns about hate crimes have become increasingly prominent among policymakers, with hate crimes defined as criminal offenses motivated by bias against a person's characteristics.
• Congress has enacted several laws to address hate crimes, including the Civil Rights Act of 1968 and the Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act of 2009.
• The Matthew Shepard and James Byrd, Jr. Hate Crimes Prevention Act expands the scope of hate crime victims to include gender, sexual orientation, gender identity, and disability.
• The commerce clause is a potential authority for Congress to expand hate crime legislation, but the Supreme Court's decision in United States v. Morrison narrowed its scope.
• The Court held that Congress must distinguish between national and local issues, and that its power under the commerce clause reaches only the former.
• Hate crimes that involve interstate travel may still be within the commerce clause's reach.
• Section 5 of the 14th Amendment gives Congress the power to enforce the Amendment's provisions, but the Court has limited its scope to state action, not private action.
• Section 2 of the 13th Amendment may be a more viable option for broadening hate crime legislation, as it proscribes slavery and involuntary servitude without reference to federal, state, or private action.
• Constitutional limits on hate crime legislation include the 1st Amendment's protection of free speech and the 6th Amendment's right to a jury trial, which may impact the constitutionality of hate crime statutes.
</summary>

<summary>
• An enterprise architecture is a blueprint that describes the current and desired state of an organization or functional area in both logical and technical terms, as well as a plan for transitioning between the two states.
• Without an enterprise architecture, it is unlikely that an organization will be able to transform business processes and modernize supporting systems to minimize overlap and maximize interoperability.
• The concept of enterprise architectures originated in the mid-1980s, and various frameworks for defining the content of these architectures have been published by government agencies and OMB.
• The Federal Enterprise Architecture Framework (FEAF) was published in 1999 to provide federal agencies with a common construct for their architectures.
• The Office of Management and Budget (OMB) established the Federal Enterprise Architecture Program Management Office (FEAPMO) to develop a federal enterprise architecture according to a collection of five reference models.
• The OMB's enterprise architecture assessment tool helps agencies understand the current state of their architecture and assists them in integrating architectures into their decision-making processes.
• The Enterprise Architecture Management Maturity Framework (EAMMF) provides a common benchmarking tool for assessing the management of enterprise architecture efforts and developing improvement plans.
• Most of the 27 major departments and agencies have not fully satisfied all the core elements associated with stage 2 of the EAMMF, but have satisfied a number of core elements at stages 3, 4, and 5.
• The departments and agencies reported that they have collectively invested a total of $836 million to date on enterprise architecture development, with costs ranging from $2 million to $433 million.
• The GAO recommends that the Administrators of the Environmental Protection Agency, General Services Administration, National Aeronautics and Space Administration, Small Business Administration, and U.S. Agency for International Development, and other department heads ensure that their respective enterprise architecture programs develop and implement plans for fully satisfying each of the conditions in the EAMMF.
</summary>

<summary>
• The Bureau of Land Management (BLM) manages most federal mineral development and is responsible for implementing the national mining and minerals policy, which fosters private enterprise in the development of domestic mining and minerals industries. The BLM manages a large amount of federal lands, and federal land in the National Forest System (NFS) is under the jurisdiction of the Forest Service. The Forest Service plays a role in authorizing mineral development on NFS lands.
• The leasing and permitting of onshore, federal public domain lands are governed by the Mineral Lands Leasing Act of 1920 (MLLA), which authorizes the Secretary of the Interior to lease oil and gas deposits and onshore public domain lands containing oil and gas deposits. The Secretary must provide opportunities for public participation in the development of Resource Management Plans (RMPs) and must comply with the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969 (NEPA) when analyzing NFS lands for potential leasing. The MLLA also requires the Secretary to accept the highest bid from a responsible qualified bidder in a competitive auction.
• The Energy Policy Act of 2005 (2005 EPACT) made several changes to the law governing federal oil and gas leases on public domain lands, including requiring the Secretary of the Interior and the Secretary of Agriculture to enter into a memorandum of understanding regarding the processing of oil and gas lease applications. The 2005 EPACT also requires the Secretary of the Interior to establish a Federal Permit Streamlining Pilot Project and to ensure expeditious compliance with NEPA. The Act also established that certain actions taken by the Secretary of the Interior or the Secretary of Agriculture are subject to a rebuttable presumption that the use of a categorical exclusion under NEPA would apply.
</summary>

<summary>
* The role of U.S. Chiefs of Mission (COM) has expanded since World War II, with COMs now responsible for overseeing nearly all U.S. government activities in their country of assignment, except for military operations. COMs serve as the President's personal representative, leading diplomatic efforts and exercising authority through their leadership of the embassy's "country team." The State Department's 2010 Quadrennial Diplomacy and Development Review (QDDR) emphasizes the need to equip COMs to better perform their role, highlighting the importance of coordination among U.S. agencies. COMs are responsible for promoting U.S. goods and services for export to their host country.
* COM authority is derived from the President's general constitutional powers in foreign affairs, as well as legislative provisions and executive branch directives. Section 207 of the Foreign Service Act of 1980 (FSA 1980) sets out the three main components of COM authority: responsibilities, authority over personnel, and obligations of U.S. government personnel and agencies. COMs have full responsibility for the direction, coordination, and supervision of all U.S. government executive branch employees in their country of assignment, except for certain personnel. COMs also have authority over the personnel stationed at the embassy and in the country of assignment.
* The effectiveness of COM authority in practice has been questioned, with some analysts raising concerns about the ability of COMs to manage their embassies and exert their authority. The State Department's Office of Inspector General (OIG) has identified weaknesses in COM leadership and management, citing reduced productivity, low morale, and stress-related curtailments of tours of duty. To improve COM performance, institutions have proposed selecting potential ambassadors for interagency experience and expertise, and standardizing the education and training of potential ambassadors. The Foreign Service Institute (FSI) has taken steps to enhance its training course for new COMs, including creating a new handbook on COM interagency leadership.

<summary>
* The Endangered Species Act (ESA) provides for the listing and protection of species that are endangered or threatened with extinction.
* Federal agencies are required to consult with the Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) or the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) to determine whether an agency project might jeopardize the continued existence of listed species.
* The consultation process concludes with the appropriate Service issuing a biological opinion (BiOp) as to the harm the project poses.
* If a project could jeopardize a species, a jeopardy opinion is released along with any reasonable and prudent alternatives (RPAs) to the agency action that would avoid jeopardy.
* The exemption process is available for federal projects that cannot be conducted without jeopardizing species, and it offers the opportunity to consider extraordinary economic circumstances.
* The exemption process is used so rarely, with only six instances in which an exemption was sought, and only two in which it was granted.
* The Endangered Species Committee (ESC) reviews applications for exemptions and is responsible for the ultimate decision.
* The ESC is composed of top government officials, including the Secretary of the Interior, the Secretary of Agriculture, and the Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisors.
* The exemption process is complex and can take up to 280 days, and even if an exemption is granted, controversy and legal challenges may continue.
* The ESA has strong legal protections for listed species, and the exemption process is rarely invoked due to the stringency of the process and the potential consequences of extinction.
</summary>

<summary>

* The exchange rate policies of East Asian nations, particularly China, Japan, and South Korea, have been a source of tension with the United States in the past and remain so in the present. Some analysts argue that these countries have intentionally kept their currencies undervalued to maintain price competitiveness in global markets. This is seen as a form of "currency manipulation" that violates Article IV of the International Monetary Fund's Articles of Agreement.
* The Trade Facilitation and Trade Enforcement Act of 2015 requires the Department of the Treasury to analyze exchange rates and externally-oriented policies of major trading partners. The report found that no major trading partner met all three criteria for currency manipulation in the current reporting period. However, six major trading partners, including China, Japan, and South Korea, were placed on a "Monitoring List" for close attention to their currency practices.
* East Asian governments have adopted various exchange rate policies, ranging from a "fixed" or "pegged" exchange rate to a "free float" policy. A "managed float" policy is the most common, where the value of the currency is allowed to fluctuate until certain economic indicators reach critical levels. This policy allows for greater autonomy in domestic monetary policy while minimizing exchange-rate risk.
* Hong Kong has maintained a "linked" exchange rate with the U.S. dollar since 1983, while Japan, the Philippines, and South Korea have allowed their currencies to float freely in foreign exchange markets. However, all three nations have intervened in international currency markets to influence fluctuations in the exchange rate. This has led to allegations of currency manipulation and intervention.
* The International Monetary Fund (IMF) categorizes exchange rate policies into four categories: free float, managed float, pegged, and currency board. Only Japan allows its currency to float freely, while five nations allow their currencies to float but reserve the right to intervene. Seven countries manage their exchange rates according to certain economic objectives.
* China's exchange rate policy has been a subject of controversy, with some analysts arguing that it has abandoned its "crawling peg" policy in favor of a pegged exchange rate. However, others argue that the stability of the renminbi with respect to the U.S. dollar is an artifact of the basket of currencies being used by China. China has allowed the renminbi to appreciate in recent years, but has also intervened in foreign exchange markets to prevent a rapid depreciation.
* The renminbi bloc, a group of Southeast Asian countries that follow the appreciation of China's RMB

<summary>
• The Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Extension Act of 2007 (P.L. 110-173) was signed into law on December 29, 2007, to extend funding for these programs and make various changes to their operations.
• The Act suspended the Medicare physician payment cut scheduled to take effect in 2008 and provided SCHIP funding through March 2009.
• It also extended a number of expiring provisions and programs, including Medicare Advantage plans, Medicaid payments, and the State Children's Health Insurance Program (SCHIP).
• The Act included funding for miscellaneous activities, such as grants for Area Agencies on Aging and Aging and Disability Resource Centers, and the State Health Insurance Assistance Programs.
• It also extended the Title V Abstinence Education block grant through June 30, 2008, and amended the Public Health Service Act to provide for research into the prevention of Type I diabetes.
• The Act included provisions to improve the collection of data on state populations of low-income children and to strengthen procedures for determining Medicare's responsibility as a secondary rather than primary payer for covered services.
• The Congressional Budget Office estimated that the Act would result in a net savings to the federal government of $100 million between FY2008 and FY2012.
</summary>

<summary>
• Policymakers are considering reforming or limiting itemized tax deductions for individuals to increase federal tax revenue, simplify the tax code, and reduce incentives for inefficient economic behavior. However, some argue that limits on deductions could have adverse economic effects or change the distributional burden of the federal income tax code. Analysis of tax filer data is informing discussions about itemized tax deduction reform.
• Itemized deductions are optional and can be claimed by tax filers who have aggregate itemized deductions greater than the standard deduction. Tax filers who itemize must report each item separately on their tax returns and provide documentation in the event of an IRS audit. The tax benefit of choosing to itemize is the amount that their itemized deductions exceed the standard deduction multiplied by their top marginal income tax rate.
• Higher-income tax filers tend to itemize their deductions more often than lower-income tax filers. In 2014, 30% of all tax filers chose to itemize their deductions, with a greater share of higher-income individuals choosing to itemize. The share of tax filers who chose to itemize in income ranges above $200,000 remained virtually the same (over 90%).
• The majority of itemizers (56.2%) had incomes less than $100,000, and 86.8% of itemizers had an AGI less than $200,000. A majority (63.6%) of total itemized deduction claims were made by itemizers with an AGI greater than $100,000. Tax filers with an AGI more than $1 million comprised 0.8% of itemizers but claimed 13.1% of all itemized tax deductions in 2014.
• Specific deductions tend to benefit different types of itemizers based on their income. Tax filers in higher-income ranges claimed deductions for charitable gifts, state and local income taxes, and real estate property taxes at higher rates than tax filers in lower-income ranges. The deduction for charitable gifts was claimed by 37% of tax filers with an AGI between $50,000 and $100,000.
• Some itemized deductions are classified as tax expenditures, or losses in federal tax revenue. The deduction for state and local income or sales taxes is estimated to be the itemized deduction with the largest tax expenditure estimate in FY2018, accounting for 5.5% ($74.1 billion) of all individual tax expenditures. <summary>

* The tax treatment of capital gains and losses has been a topic of debate in Congress since the enactment of the individual income tax in 1913. The tax treatment of capital gains and losses has changed repeatedly over the years, with some changes attempting to reestablish symmetry between the tax treatment of capital gains and capital losses. The current tax system allows for the deduction of capital losses against ordinary income, but with a limit of $3,000 per year. This limit was originally enacted to prevent taxpayers from minimizing their income tax liabilities by altering the timing of the realization of gains and losses.
* The tax treatment of capital gains and losses is asymmetrical, with long-term gains taxed at a maximum rate of 15% and long-term losses deductible without limit against short-term capital gains and net long-term losses. This asymmetry allows taxpayers to time their gains and losses to minimize their income taxes. For example, a taxpayer can realize and deduct losses in one tax year at 35% while waiting until the next tax year to realize and pay taxes on gains at 15%. This creates an incentive for taxpayers to sell assets with losses and hold assets with gains.
* The empirical evidence indicates that capital gains income is heavily concentrated in the upper income ranges, and it is probable that large capital losses are also concentrated in the same income ranges. Taxpayers in the middle income ranges tend to hold capital gains-producing assets as part of tax-favored retirement savings plans, which are not affected by the net loss restrictions. The benefits of increasing the net loss deduction would tend to accrue to taxpayers in the upper income ranges. This is because the tax benefits of an increase in the net capital loss limitation would be received by a relatively small number of higher income individuals.
* The current tax system allows for an unlimited carry forward of excess losses, which means that taxpayers do not forfeit the full value of excess losses because they can deduct those losses in future years. The actual cost to the taxpayer of forgoing the full loss in the current year is the interest that would have been earned on the additional tax reduction that would have been realized had there been no excess loss limitation. For example, a taxpayer with a net long-term capital loss of $20,000 can deduct the entire loss against other income in the first year and reduce their income tax liability by $7,000. However, if the taxpayer had no net capital gains in any subsequent year, it would take seven years to deduct the full $20,000 capital loss.

* The National Labor Relations Act (NLRA) recognizes the right of employees to engage in collective bargaining through representatives of their own choosing, and it attempts to mitigate and eliminate labor-related obstructions to the free flow of commerce. Although union membership has declined dramatically since the 1950s, congressional interest in the NLRA remains significant. In the 112th Congress, over 30 bills have been introduced to amend the NLRA.
* The NLRA does not apply to all individuals employed by an employer, but only to "employees" who are defined as individuals who do not include any individual employed as a supervisor. The term "supervisor" is defined by the Act to include any individual with the authority to perform certain functions, if the exercise of such authority requires the use of independent judgment. The NLRB and U.S. Supreme Court have sought to provide meaning to this language.
* In NLRB v. Kentucky River Community Care, Inc., the Court considered whether certain nurses should be classified as supervisors for purposes of the NLRA. The Court ultimately affirmed the Sixth Circuit's decision, which understood section 2(11) of the NLRA to set forth a three-part test for determining supervisory status. The Court believed that the NLRB's reference to "ordinary or technical judgment" established a "startling categorical exclusion" that was not suggested by the NLRA's statutory text.
* In Oakwood Healthcare, Inc., the NLRB defined the terms "assign," "responsibly to direct," and "independent judgment" as they are used in section 2(11) of the NLRA. The NLRB concluded that 12 permanent charge nurses assigned to five of the 10 patient care units were supervisors for purposes of the NLRA. The NLRB determined that the charge nurses exercised independent judgment in accordance with section 2(11).
* Section 8(a)(1) of the NLRA prohibits an employer from interfering with the right of employees to engage in collective bargaining, and the NLRB has suggested that Congress did not intend for section 8(b)(1)(A) to be given the broad application sometimes accorded to section 8(a)(1). The NLRB has indicated that section 8(b)(1)(A) broadly interdicts any union conduct threatening job security of employees because of the employees' refusal or failure to abide by union membership conditions.
