<summary>

• Cardiovascular disease is the leading cause of mortality in many economically developed nations, accounting for about 30% of all deaths, and its incidence is still increasing. Ongoing research aims to investigate and prevent the early development of cardiovascular risk factors such as atherosclerosis, hypertension, dyslipidemia, chronic inflammation, and insulin resistance. The beneficial effects of n-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (n-3 PUFAs) were proved in several observational and experimental studies. The lipid-lowering action of n-3 PUFAs was detected at the beginning, so these nutrients were used for the treatment of dyslipidemic disorders.

• The beneficial effects of n-3 PUFAs include anti-inflammatory, antithrombotic, antiatherosclerotic, and antiarrhythmogenic effects. Low-grade chronic inflammation is now recognized as a prominent process in the development of atherosclerosis and coronary heart disease. The induction of inflammation may well provide a link between hyperlipidemia and atherogenesis. Atherosclerosis is now considered a systemic disease featured by low-grade arterial inflammatory lesions that can develop through the disease progression.

• In physiological conditions, endothelial cells synthesize and release adequate amounts of nitric oxide (NO) and prostaglandins and maintain a downstream balance between pro- and anti-inflammatory molecules. However, in the presence of atherosclerosis, this balance disrupts, leading towards an increase in the production of pro-inflammatory cytokines. These pro-inflammatory cytokines can induce oxidative stress by enhancing the production of reactive oxygen species (ROS) by monocytes, macrophages, and leukocytes. PUFAs and their eicosanoid derivatives may play a significant role in modulating the inflammatory response.

• Unsaturated fatty acids are referred to as PUFAs when two or more double bonds are present. There are two PUFA families, omega-3 (n-3) and omega-6 (n-6) fatty acids, which differ in the location of the last double bond relative to the terminal methyl end of the molecule. The human body can produce almost all fatty acids, except linoleic acid (LA) and alpha-linolenic acid (ALA), which are named essential fatty acids because the body cannot synthesize them. Endogenous conversion of the initial C18 PUFA precursors results in the synthesis of longer-chain counterparts.

• Neovascular age-related macular degeneration (NAMD) is a leading cause of visual loss among the elderly population, and intravitreal anti-vascular endothelial growth factor (anti-VEGF) agents have improved treatment outcomes. Before the introduction of anti-VEGF agents, only a limited number of patients achieved prevention of visual acuity loss with different treatment options. The introduction of bevacizumab and ranibizumab has led to significant improvements in visual acuity for the majority of patients.
• A multicenter study compared the efficacy of bevacizumab and ranibizumab in treating NAMD, and the results showed that both drugs were effective in preventing visual acuity loss and improving visual acuity in some patients. The study also found that the two drugs had similar effects in the treatment of NAMD. However, the safety of the drugs remains unclear, and there is an ongoing debate about this issue.
• The present study aimed to compare the functional and anatomical outcomes of bevacizumab therapy to ranibizumab therapy on an as-needed treatment regimen for NAMD in Turkish patients. The study included 79 patients in the bevacizumab group and 74 patients in the ranibizumab group, and the results showed that both groups had significant improvements in visual acuity and central retinal thickness. The two groups were similar in terms of baseline characteristics and treatment outcomes.
• The study found that the mean visual acuity and central retinal thickness were significantly better than baseline at every time point in both groups. However, there was no statistically significant difference between the two groups in terms of change in visual acuity and central retinal thickness. The mean number of injections at month 12 was similar between the two groups.
• The study's results are consistent with previous clinical studies that have found similar improvements in visual and anatomical outcomes with bevacizumab and ranibizumab. The study also found that the rate of patients who were stable in terms of visual acuity results was similar to previous studies. The study's findings suggest that both bevacizumab and ranibizumab are effective in treating NAMD and improving visual acuity.
</summary>

• Rudolf Virchow, a 19th-century Prussian physician-scientist, is widely regarded as the father of modern pathology and proposed that cancer arises from initially normal cells in response to chronic irritation or inflammation. His ideas set the stage for further research on the relationship between inflammation and cancer.

• Pelayo Correa, a pathologist from Colombia, devoted his career to understanding the etiology of gastric cancer and published a model for gastric cancer development in 1975, which proposed a stepwise process from chronic atrophic gastritis to intestinal metaplasia and cancer. The initial changes were postulated to occur in the first decade of life, when H. pylori colonization occurs.

• Correa initially thought that the agent(s) responsible for promoting this slow progression from gastritis to cancer were environmental, based on studies of migrants from high gastric cancer risk areas. However, he later focused on the role of H. pylori in gastric cancer.

• Robin Warren and Barry Marshall, who were awarded the Nobel Prize in Physiology or Medicine in 2005, discovered H. pylori and its role in gastritis and peptic ulcer disease in the 1970s and 1980s. They showed that H. pylori causes gastritis and ulcer disease, and their work laid the foundation for further research on the relationship between H. pylori and gastric cancer.

• Initial investigations into a possible association of H. pylori with gastric cancer provided only weak evidence for a link between H. pylori and gastric cancer in the 1980s and early 1990s. However, subsequent studies found a positive correlation between H. pylori seroprevalence and gastric cancer.

• The World Health Organization's International Agency for Research on Cancer declared H. pylori a definite carcinogen in 1994, based on the results of three large cohorts with nested case-controls. These studies found that evidence of prior H. pylori infection was significantly more common in those subjects who subsequently developed gastric cancer.

• H. pylori eradication can reduce the risk of developing gastric cancer, and recent meta-analyses of underpowered studies indicate that H. pylori eradication decreases the risk of gastric cancer development by approximately 40% in primary prevention and by 54% as a tertiary prevention strategy. However, it is uncertain if similar reductions can be extrapolated to regions where noncardia gastric cancer is less common.

* Preeclampsia (PE) is a leading cause of maternal and neonatal mortality and morbidity, complicating 25% of all pregnancies. The disease is characterized by the presence of proteinuria in women with gestational hypertension. However, several studies have shown that proteinuria is not a significant predictor of adverse maternal and neonatal outcomes. The incidence of PE increased in China after the opening of the two-child policy, but there was no indicator of severe PE.
* Severe PE is often combined with hypoalbuminemia, which may serve as an indicator of the severity of PE. Hypoalbuminemia occurs mainly due to systemic small vessel spasm, increased secretion of angiotensin, and damaged vascular endothelial cells. This leads to a large number of proteins and liquid leaking into tissues, causing intravascular dehydration. Intravascular dehydration may accelerate the appearance of intravascular lesions, which is thought to be a predisposing factor of HELLP syndrome and acute fatty liver of pregnancy.
* The aim of the study was to evaluate maternal and perinatal outcomes in women with PE, according to the different value of albumin (25 g/L and <25 g/L). A total of 299 women from the Maternal and Child Health Hospital of Anhui Province were enrolled between January 2014 and June 2015. The study was approved by the Anhui Medical University Ethics Committee, and written informed consent was obtained from all participants. Serum albumin was measured at the laboratory of the Maternal and Child Health Hospital of Anhui Province using the UniCel DxC800 of Beckman Coulter.
* The study included 220 women with mild hypoproteinemia (MHP) and 79 women with severe hypoproteinemia (SHP). The analysis showed that women with SHP were delivered almost 1.5 weeks earlier than the MHP group. The percentage of cesarean sections was higher, and the rate of spontaneous delivery was lower in the SHP group. Severe hypertension was more frequent in the SHP group than in the MHP group.
* Neonatal outcomes were worse in the SHP group, with a significantly lighter average birth weight (2498.1 ± 866.5 g) compared to the MHP group (2940.1 ± 768.0 g). * Researchers have identified hundreds of immunologically recognized proteins associated with prostate tissue that could serve as targets for anti-tumor vaccines.
* The study used machine-learning algorithms to analyze serum samples from patients with prostate cancer treated with different therapies, including androgen deprivation and vaccines, to identify biomarkers of immune response.
* The results showed that antigen-specific IgG immune responses were elicited as a result of prostate-directed immune-active therapies, and the patterns of response differed with respect to the individual therapy.
* The study suggests that serum antibody responses to a panel of prostate tissue- and prostate cancer-associated antigens could be developed as a diagnostic tool to evaluate immune responses elicited following immune-active therapies.
</summary>

* Male Wistar rats were used in the study to develop a non-traumatic osteonecrosis (ONFH) animal model. The rats were given lipopolysaccharide (LPS) and methylprednisolone to promote the development of ONFH.
* The rats were divided into two groups: weight-bearing (WB) and non-weight-bearing (NWB) groups. The WB group was allowed to walk and move independently, while the NWB group was suspended in a head-down tilted position to prevent weight bearing on the hindlimbs.
* The study found that both WB and NWB groups developed ONFH at a comparable rate, indicating that weight bearing does not contribute to the initial development of non-traumatic ONFH. The femoral heads of the rats were examined using histopathological analysis to assess the presence of osteonecrosis.
* The results of the study suggest that the rat model may help elucidate the pathogenesis of ONFH and devise a prevention strategy, but may not be useful for observing the mechanism of femoral head collapse. The aetiology, pathogenesis, and prognosis of non-traumatic ONFH remain unclear.
</summary>

• The study explores the use of piezoelectric materials to stimulate bone growth at the bone-implant interface. The converse piezoelectric effect was used to mechanically stimulate bone with polyvinylidene fluoride films. The films were coated with acrylic and bone-like particles to improve cell adhesion and electrical insulation. The displacement was higher where the cells were seeded, in the central area of the coated devices.
• The study found that the total bone area around the actuators was significantly higher compared to static controls. The increment of bone occupied area was due to new bone formation, and in actuators, the area occupied by woven bone and osteoid was 64.89% of the total bone area. The mineral apposition rate was significantly higher around actuated devices than around static devices. The results suggest that the generated strains were low but enough to elicit a response.
• The study also found that the expression of osteopontin (OPN) was significantly higher around actuators compared to static controls. OPN is a multifunctional noncollagenous glycoprotein present in bone matrix, and its production is known to be increased in association with mechanical loading. The results suggest that the piezoelectric materials and the converse piezoelectric effect may be used to effectively stimulate bone growth at the bone-implant interface. However, new materials should be developed aiming better biocompatibility for future studies.
</summary>

• Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) is a group of inherited disorders that cause a deficiency in an adrenal enzyme, resulting in altered cortisol and aldosterone secretion. The most frequent variant, 21-hydroxylase deficiency, accounts for 95% of affected patients and is caused by inactivating mutations in the 21-hydroxylase gene (CYP21A2).
• The study investigated 26 patients with CAH due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency and found that 42.3% of them showed MRI abnormalities, including white matter hyperintensities and temporal lobe structures dysgenesis. The abnormalities were more common in patients with poor hormonal control due to non-compliance with medication.
• The study suggests that chronic hyperandrogenism, a result of non-compliance with treatment, may be the main mechanism involved in the genesis of brain MRI abnormalities in CAH patients. The abnormalities could also be related to hormonal imbalance during brain development and corticosteroid treatment.
• The study's findings are consistent with previous reports of brain MRI abnormalities in CAH patients, which have implicated hormonal imbalance and corticosteroid treatment as potential contributing factors. Further studies are required to define the relationships between brain involvement and different CAH phenotypes and treatment regimens.
</summary>

• The study was conducted in the Department of Oral Medicine and Radiology and a Cancer Centre, with a sample of 90 individuals divided into a study group of 60 OSCC patients and a control group of 30 healthy volunteers.
• The study group consisted of OSCC patients between the ages of 25 and 75 years with histologically proven oral cancer, while the control group consisted of healthy volunteers aged 25-75 years without any history of debilitating systemic illness.
• Serum L-fucose levels were estimated using a clinical chemistry autoanalyzer, and the results showed a significant difference between OSCC patients and healthy controls.
• The mean serum L-fucose level of OSCC patients was 10.85 mg/dl, while that of healthy controls was 3.47 mg/dl, with a difference of 7.38 mg/dl.
• Statistical analysis revealed a significant p-value (p < 0.001), indicating a positive correlation between serum L-fucose levels and OSCC stages.
• The study found that serum L-fucose levels increased progressively with the stage of cancer, with stage IV showing the highest level.
• The results suggest that serum L-fucose levels can be used as a biochemical indicator of cancer detection, staging, therapeutic success, prognosis, and post-treatment evaluation.
• Further investigation on a large scale is recommended to confirm serum L-fucose as an effective tumor marker in the diagnosis and management of oral cancer.
</summary>

• The generation of humanized monoclonal antibodies (mAbs) that inhibit the interaction of VEGF-A with its receptors and the development of small-molecule protein tyrosine kinase (PTK) inhibitors have provided avenues to explore the efficacy of targeting the VEGF-A signaling pathway in cancer. These approaches have led to the success of Avastin (bevacizumab) in treating various human cancers.
• However, the recent withdrawal of Avastin for treating breast cancer in the US has highlighted the limitations of anti-angiogenic treatments and the need for a careful cost-benefit analysis to ensure that scarce healthcare resources are well spent in cancer treatment. The development of resistance to Avastin and pre-existing refractoriness of some tumors suggest the role of other growth factors in sustaining tumor angiogenesis.
• Alternative ligands for the angiogenic receptor VEGFR-2, such as VEGF-C and VEGF-D, and other angiogenic factors from distinct growth factor families, are logical candidates for promoting resistance to Avastin. These factors may also contribute to the development of resistance through mechanisms such as vascular mimicry and altered tumor metabolism.
• The growth factors VEGF-C and VEGF-D have been shown to promote tumor angiogenesis and lymphangiogenesis, and targeting these factors may be a viable approach for anti-cancer therapy. Mabs specific to the VHD of VEGF-D or PTK inhibitors that block VEGFR-2 and VEGFR-3 signaling could be employed to inhibit tumor growth and metastatic spread.
• Further studies are needed to understand the complex network of signaling cascades that drive angiogenesis, lymphangiogenesis, and resistance to anti-angiogenic drugs. Genome-wide functional approaches and the development of specific mAbs targeting VEGF family members and their receptors may provide effective therapeutic strategies for cancer treatment.
</summary>

• Malaria remains a significant public health concern in many countries, including Iran, particularly in the south and southeast regions. Deliberate implementation of control measures has resulted in a substantial reduction of malaria incidence in Iran in recent years. Malaria cases were reduced from 11,460 in 2008 to 3,239 in 2011.

• In Iran, P. vivax is responsible for the majority of malaria cases, while P. falciparum accounts for 1-15% of the cases. Iran entered the malaria pre-elimination program in 2009 and interventions such as preventing strategies, active case detection, and timely appropriate treatment of patients have been performed in all endemic areas of the country. Early recognition of all parasite carriers bearing various disease symptoms and parasite rates is crucial for achieving malaria elimination.

• Active surveillance by precise laboratory methods in endemic areas provides an appropriate tool for detection of all kinds of infections, particularly asymptomatic ones containing low parasite densities. Asymptomatic malaria infections were described in hyper-endemic regions following frequent infective bites and repetitive immune system response toward the parasite attenuating parasitemia to undetectable levels in blood smear. The prevalence of this kind of malaria infection was determined by means of different laboratory techniques in various endemic countries previously.

• The aim of this study was to detect low parasite and asymptomatic malaria infections by means of three malaria diagnostic tests (microscopy, RDT, and nested-PCR) in a low transmission region of Bagh-e-Malek in Minab district, Hormozgan province, southern Iran. The study was performed as a cross-sectional survey in Bagh-e-Malek region, which is located in Minab district, southeast of Hormozgan province. A total of 200 healthy volunteers were participated in this study from Bagh-e-Malek area.

• The study used three diagnostic methods: microscopy, RDT, and nested-PCR. Microscopy is the most commonly used method of malaria diagnosis as the gold standard in Iran, but it has limitations associated with this method. Chromatographic rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) are introduced in remote settings, where microscopic diagnosis is either impractical or unfeasible.

• The results of this investigation showed that no Plasmodium parasite was detected in any examined sample using microscopy and RDT tests. However, nested-PCR amplification found three P. vivax positive samples (1.5%) in asymptomatic individuals. These cases were considered as asymptomatic malaria patients since

* A prototype was developed to measure the bracket debonding force in vivo using a strain gauge connected directly to the pliers where the bracket debonding occurs.
* The prototype was tested in vitro and in vivo, and the results showed that the bond strength obtained with the prototype was statistically similar to the bond strength obtained with a universal testing machine.
* The prototype was found to be a useful tool for measuring bond strength in vivo, and it was shown to be a safe method for preserving the enamel surface.
* The study highlights the importance of determining the minimum bond strength values required for safe clinical performance of orthodontic bonding procedures, and the need for a device to measure the bracket debonding force directly in the oral cavity.
</summary>

* * Urinary tract infections (UTIs) are a common problem in infants and young children, with varying frequencies, symptoms, and causative organisms depending on sex, age, and gender. The frequency and symptoms of UTIs in neonates are non-specific and often warrant a complete sepsis workup. A 7-14 day course of antibiotic therapy, typically parenteral ampicillin plus an aminoglycoside or a third-generation cephalosporin, is usually prescribed. 
* * Recent reports have shown emerging patterns of resistance to empirical antibiotics, making the early choice of antibiotics a more challenging decision. The criticalness of the issue lies in the fact that early diagnosis and treatment can prevent long-term consequences and reduce the burden on healthcare systems. 
* * Clinical manifestations of UTIs in neonates are mostly non-specific and of a systemic nature, including fever, irritability, lethargy, vomiting, growth failure, abnormal urination, and jaundice. The non-specific presentations often make UTIs hard to diagnose, with reported prevalence ranging from 4-25% in very low birth weight infants to 0.1-1% in term infants. 
* * UTIs in newborns can lead to urosepsis or neonatal sepsis, which is why they are often managed as a case of sepsis. Most UTIs in infants are caused by gram-negative bacilli, with E. coli being the most prevalent organism, accounting for up to 80% of isolates in many studies. 
* * A study was conducted to retrospectively review all UTI cases managed in an inpatient setting of a neonatal division over an eight-year period. The study aimed to determine the frequency of UTI causative organisms in neonates admitted to the neonatal division of Bahrami Children's Hospital. 
* * The study found that E. coli was the most prevalent organism, causing 64.4% of UTIs, followed by Enterobacter, Klebsiella, and S. epidermidis. The study also found that E. coli was resistant to ampicillin in 93.6% of cases, ceftizoxime in 78.9% of cases, and gentamycin in 59.5% of cases.

* * Nurses in Kenya have not been adequately involved in national policy development, with many feeling excluded from policy decisions and lacking opportunities to contribute to policy processes. The study found that nurses were not involved in policy formulation, and their input was often limited to representing nursing issues at selected policy tables. Nonnursing decision-makers also felt that nurses were not adequately involved in national policy-making processes. The study highlighted the need for nurses to be more involved in policy-making to improve health service delivery and inform health systems strengthening.
* * The study identified several reasons for nurses' underengagement in policy, including lack of knowledge and skills, inadequate representation on policy-related structures, and a top-down approach to policy-making. Nonnursing decision-makers felt that nurses had inadequate knowledge about the policy-making process and lacked skills to engage in this process. Nurse leaders concurred that nurses did not generally understand the broader issues outside nursing that were necessary to influence policies. The study suggested that nurses need to be empowered through training to enable them to better understand and participate in policy formulation.
* * The study found that hierarchies and structures within the health care system, including health systems hierarchies, interprofessional hierarchies, and intraprofessional hierarchies, hindered nurses' active engagement in policy processes. Medical doctors were identified as the dominant policy decision-makers at various levels of the health care system. The study suggested that nurses need to be given more opportunities to engage in decision-making at all levels and that mechanisms should be established to allow nurses' views to be heard at the national level. The study also highlighted the need for nurses to be educated in broader health systems issues and become patient advocates for health care.
* * The study recommended that policy-makers address hierarchies, domination, and gender issues inherent in the health care system to enhance nurses' participation in policy-making. The study suggested that nurses should be given orientation on existing national policies and how these policies are affecting their work environment and patient outcomes. Nurses should also be encouraged to unite to build a strong voice to advocate for improvements in national policies that affect their work and quality of care. The study highlighted the need for nurses to develop skills in research and conduct both health systems and clinical research to inform policy-making decisions.
* * The study concluded that nurses in Kenya need to understand the policy cycle and have knowledge and competencies in policy formulation, implementation, and evaluation to effectively influence policy decisions. The study suggested that nursing educators should introduce a course on policy and policy processes, as well

* The study was conducted on LCN2 mice, which were generated by gene targeting in embryonic stem cells from mouse strain 129, and targeted ES cells were injected into C57BL/6 blastocysts. The LCN2-null mice were backcrossed onto the B6 background for 10 generations before mice were used for the experiments. Heterozygous mating scheme was used to generate wild-type and LCN2 mice for the experiments.
* The mice were housed in a specific pathogen-free facility at the University of Minnesota, and animal handling followed the National Institutes of Health guidelines. Experimental procedures were approved by the University of Minnesota Animal Care and Use Committee. Age-matched male wild-type and LCN2 mice were allocated into groups and fed an HFD (fat calories: 60%) or a regular chow diet (RCD).
* The study aimed to investigate the role of LCN2 in lipid metabolism, adaptive thermoregulation, and diet-induced obesity and insulin resistance in vivo. LCN2 mice were found to be more susceptible to HFD-induced obesity, dyslipidemia, fatty liver, glucose intolerance, and insulin resistance. The study also explored the mechanisms underlying these phenotypes.
* The results showed that LCN2 mice gained more body weight when fed HFD or aged, and increased body fat mass together with enlarged multiple organs may largely account for increased body weight in LCN2 mice under the RCD condition. Wild-type and LCN2 mice at a young age did not demonstrate significantly different metabolic phenotypes when fed RCD. However, LCN2 mice developed more severe systemic insulin resistance, hyperglycemia, hyperinsulinemia, and hypoadiponectinemia under the HFD condition.
* One of the most profound phenotypic features of LCN2 mice is cold sensitivity and lower body temperature under thermal stress conditions. Nonshivering thermogenesis is used to maintain constant body temperature and energy balance, controlling body weight, especially in small mammals. Both neural and hormonal signals, including norepinephrine, epinephrine, thyroid hormones, glucagon, insulin, glucocorticoid, and leptin, are known to regulate thermogenesis.
* The study found that 5-h cold exposure leads to a significant increase in LCN2 expression in white adipose tissue (WAT), which is in agreement with a recent study. In the absence of LCN2, mice were cold intolerant and failed to maintain the body temperature

• The study aimed to evaluate the role of urethral plate characters in the success of tip urethroplasty for primary anterior penile hypospadias in 100 children. The study found that the width of the urethral plate was a significant predictor of postoperative complications, with patients having a plate width < 8 mm experiencing a higher fistula rate.
• Patients with a narrow urethral plate (< 8 mm) had a statistically significant higher fistula rate compared to those with a wider plate (> 8 mm), with 26% of patients in the narrow plate group experiencing fistula formation. The narrow plate group also had a higher incidence of failed 8 fr calibration.
• The study also found that the character of the urethral plate, specifically flat plates, was associated with a higher fistula rate and failed 8 fr calibration, although the results were not statistically significant. The authors suggested that urethral plate augmentation may be necessary for patients with flat and narrow urethral plates.
• The study concluded that tip urethroplasty is a reliable and effective technique for hypospadias repair, with good cosmetic and functional results, and offers several advantages, including preservation of the urethral plate and a single suture line of the neourethra. However, patients with flat and narrow urethral plates may require additional measures, such as urethral plate augmentation, to improve outcomes.

• The study found that different populations of Iberian wall lizards (Podarcis hispanica) in central Spain have distinct morphological characteristics and chemical signals in their femoral gland secretions, which can be used to recognize and discriminate between individuals from different populations.
• The results suggest that there may be premating reproductive isolation and cryptic speciation between some, but not all, populations of the lizard, which could be mediated by the role of chemical signals in sexual interactions.

• The delivery of the human genome draft sequence promises significant biomedical advances, but biologists must navigate vast genomic data to unlock its secrets. The genomic landscape may seem featureless, but it holds rich veins of knowledge awaiting exploitation. Surveying and signposting this landscape can guide investigators towards experiments that address specific hypotheses about gene function.

• Different communities of biologists speak in dialects that are not always mutually comprehensible, particularly with respect to the umbrella term 'function'. To address this, universal vocabularies are needed to annotate genes and make their functions accessible to all scientific communities. Websites such as LocusLink, GeneCards, and Ensembl integrate information from diverse sources relevant to individual human genes.

• There are two common ways of annotating genes: empirical observations and predicted evolutionary relationships. The latter relies on homology, where genes that arose from a common ancestor are defined as homologs, paralogs, or orthologs. Homologous gene products often have similar functions, making homology a valuable tool for predicting gene function.

• The importance of annotating the genomic landscape on the basis of homology lies in its ability to infer similar tertiary structures and functions among protein homologs. However, homology assignment indicates only an approximate direction for future empirical determination of function. It is essential to note that homology is defined on the basis of evolution, rather than function.

• Domain architectures are a key aspect of protein evolution, and domains are homologous portions of sequences that have survived the evolutionary tests of time without fragmentation. Domain families can be predicted using resources such as Pfam, SMART, and InterPro, which provide a vocabulary for protein evolution. These resources have been used to annotate the human genome draft sequences.

• The proportion of the proteome that can be annotated using these resources is low, at approximately 40-60%. However, protein sequences can be identified by their component domains rather than protein or gene names, providing a more evolutionary lens on gene function. This approach implies that a gene product's function is a synthesis of the generalized functions of its component parts.

• The study of domain families has also played a major role in understanding the evolution of chordates, with significant differences detected between the repertoires of human domain families and those of other organisms. The complexity of organisms is loosely coupled to total gene number, and the question of whether the number of representatives of a domain family in a proteome is directly related to that family's contribution to cellular and organismal function remains open. * *The study aimed to compare four commercially available online heart rate monitoring systems in team sports, specifically their use in everyday situations.* The systems tested were Polar Team Pro, Acentas Team Monitoring System, Suunto Pro Team Pack, and Activio Sport System.* The study evaluated the systems' validity, reliability, and usability in real-time monitoring of multiple individuals simultaneously.* The results showed that all systems allowed direct and real-time monitoring of several individuals at the same time.

* *The study used a quality rating system to evaluate the systems, with a focus on measurement, software, and hardware.* The rating system was divided into three main categories, with a maximum score of 500.* The study also evaluated the systems' installation and use of software and hardware.* The results showed that Polar and Acentas led the field in terms of hardware quality.

* *The study also evaluated the systems' software, with a focus on usability and features.* The results showed that Activio offered the most harmonious concept, while Polar and Acentas provided more developed software tools.* The study also compared the systems' heart rate monitoring accuracy against an electrocardiogram (ECG).* The results showed that Acentas gave the best reference with a deviation of 349 meters.

* *The study evaluated the systems' failure quota, with a focus on downtime and signal loss.* The results showed that Acentas had the lowest average downtime, while Polar and Activio had higher failure rates.* The study also evaluated the systems' operating distance, with a focus on range and accuracy.* The results showed that Acentas had the widest range of data acquisition.

* *The study also evaluated the systems' usability, with a focus on wearing comfort and ease of use.* The results showed that Polar had the best design and usability features, while Activio had a functional and useful software.* The study also compared the systems' data transmission methods, with a focus on wireless local area network (WLAN) and mobile terminals.* The results showed that Polar used WLAN for data transmission, while Activio used a mobile terminal.

* *The study concluded that each system had its advantages and disadvantages, depending on the using purpose, location, and weather.* The study recommended that users consider the specific needs of their team sports when choosing a heart rate monitoring system.* The study also suggested that further system improvements could be made based on the results.* The study's findings could be useful for coaches, trainers, and athletes in team sports.

* Lennox-Gastaut syndrome (LGS) is a catastrophic epilepsy of childhood characterized by tonic seizures, atonic seizures, and atypical absence seizures, often accompanied by cognitive impairment and behavioral disorders. The syndrome is classified as a symptomatic generalized epilepsy syndrome and is typically diagnosed between the ages of 2 and 5. The prognosis of LGS is poor, with a high risk of seizures and cognitive impairment. Treatment of LGS is challenging due to the multiple seizure types and lack of a consistent underlying etiology.
* Rufinamide is a novel anticonvulsant drug that has shown promise in treating LGS, with a significant decrease in total seizures and tonic-atomic seizures compared to placebo in a randomized controlled trial. Rufinamide has a good safety profile and is well tolerated, with minimal expected side effects. However, its role in the treatment algorithm for LGS needs to be further defined, and a larger number of patients must be treated with this medication to establish its place in the treatment armamentarium. Rufinamide may be a welcome addition to the therapeutic armamentarium for LGS, given its potential benefits and relatively low side effect profile.

* In the 1960s, McCulloch and Till proposed three functional characteristics that defined stem cells: self-renewal, proliferation, and multipotency. These characteristics were first proposed by Virchow in the 19th century. The ability to make identical copies of themselves is a key feature of stem cells.
* Stem cells have been identified in various tissues, including the lung, where they play a crucial role in airway repair and regeneration. The lung epithelial lining is composed of pseudostratified, simple columnar, and cuboidal epithelium, each with distinct stem cell populations. Proximal airways contain tracheal basal cells that are pluripotent and express keratin-5 (K5).
* In the trachea, basal cell populations expressing either K5 or K14 are capable of the functional aspects of stem cell niches. These cells can proliferate to give rise to cells of multiple phenotypes in response to airway injury. Squamous cell carcinoma frequently arises from the more proximal tracheobronchial airways, yielding centrally located tumors that often exhibit elevated levels of K5 basal cells.
* In the middle airways, mature rat Clara cells can proliferate into phenotypically diverse progeny, leading to the identification of facultative progenitor cells. Clara-cell secretory protein (CCSP)-positive cells located within neuroepithelial bodies (NEB) have been shown to proliferate to repair the airway. These NEB CCSP cells are able to independently repopulate the middle airways with phenotypically diverse progeny.
* Small cell lung carcinomas frequently arise in the mid-level bronchioles and have been shown to contain fractions of cells expressing cell surface markers associated with mid-airway stem cell subpopulations. Cells expressing CD44 have also been implicated in lung cancer progression and metastasis by the epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition (EMT). CD44-expressing cells are also resistant to chemotherapy.
* In the most distal airway, there is no consensus on the cell surface marker phenotype of representative lung stem cells. Pluripotent, NEB-independent, CCSP cells have been identified in the bronchoalveolar duct junction (BADJ) that can proliferate and self-renew in culture. However, others have argued that these CCSP/SP-C cells are insufficient as the distal lung stem cell population.

• The scientific activity of researchers is manifested through published papers, which are validated and legitimized by their peers.
• These papers can serve as indicators of the degree to which their scientific knowledge in their area of research has been developed.
• The formal means of releasing scientific publications is through national and international scientific journals indexed in databases representing various areas of knowledge.
• The main databases for health science publications include Medline/PubMed, Web of Science, Embase, and Current Contents.
• Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) is a controlled vocabulary that allows researchers to retrieve information using a more exact and standardized description of the document.
• The recovery of articles and citations can be compounded by the different ways that authors' names or institutions can be entered.
• The journals selected for publication reflect the level of productivity of a research group and the institution to which they belong.
• The Universidade de São Paulo's Faculdade de Medicina had 66 full professors during the period of 2001 to 2006, with 36.4% teaching full-time and 60.6% working intermediate shifts.
• The full professors published a total of 1,960 articles in international and national scientific journals, with 68.7% published in international journals and 31.3% in national journals.

* Trichomonas vaginalis infection is one of the most common curable sexually transmitted infections, with an estimated 173 million new cases occurring annually, according to the World Health Organization. This infection has been associated with various adverse reproductive health outcomes, including pelvic inflammatory disease, low infant birth weight, and premature delivery. Furthermore, trichomoniasis has been shown to increase the transmission and acquisition of other sexually transmitted diseases, including HIV infection.
* The frequency of trichomonal infection is not monitored in most countries, and control programs do not exist. In Peru, the STI guidelines do not include trichomonas diagnostic testing, and the syndromic management of suspected vaginal trichomoniasis is the current standard for clinical care. This may lead to both over and under treatment of the infection.
* A study was conducted in Peru to investigate the prevalence and risk factors of trichomonal infection among socially marginalized women from low-income communities. The study recruited 308 women from 20 low-income communities in coastal Peru between 2003 and 2005. The participants were interviewed and underwent biological testing for various sexually transmitted infections.
* The study found that women with trichomonal infection were more likely to be older, have less education, and be single. They were also more likely to have had unprotected sex with a non-steady partner and to have multiple sex partners. The prevalence of trichomonal infection was not significantly different between women with or without recent painful urination or vaginal discharge.
* The study's findings suggest that trichomonal infection is often asymptomatic and can be missed by screening programs focused on younger age women. The infection can lead to long-term prevalent infection that does not spontaneously resolve, contributing to continued spread of the infection in the population. The asymptomatic nature of trichomonal infection also makes syndromic management unlikely to impact the population burden of infection.
* The study's results indicate that there is no direct relationship between trichomonal infection and symptoms, making syndromic treatment unlikely to impact the population burden of infection. The study's sample size was small, which limited the power to assess multivariate models between demographic and behavioral characteristics and trichomonal infection. The results may not be generalizable to other female populations.
* The study's findings support the need for improved disease control activities to reduce adverse trichomoniasis-associated reproductive health outcomes, such as ectopic pregnancy, low infant birth weight, preterm labor, and non-HPV

• The study aimed to investigate the prevalence of internet addiction and its association with psychopathology in college-going students in Mumbai, India. The study used a cross-sectional survey design and collected data from 987 students, with 681 females and 306 males.
• The results showed that 74.5% of the students were moderate users, 24.8% were possible addicts, and 0.7% were addicts, with males being more likely to be addicted. The addicts had poor mental, physical, and mental health scores, with high anxiety, depression, and anxiety-depression scores.
• The study's findings are consistent with previous studies that suggest internet addiction is more common in males and is associated with poor mental health outcomes. The study highlights the need for early intervention and detection of underlying psychopathology in individuals with internet addiction.
</summary>

<summary>
* Pancreatic cancer is a devastating disease with the highest mortality and lowest survival rates among all cancers in the US, with approximately 44,000 new diagnoses and 37,000 deaths per year. The majority of pancreatic cancer cases are pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC), which has the most aggressive tumor biology and metastatic potential. The median survival time after PDAC diagnosis is about four months, with only 19% of patients surviving past one year and 2% surviving past five years.
* The survival of patients diagnosed with PDAC may vary significantly depending on demographic characteristics, pathologic nature of the tumor, and type of treatment. Cox proportional regression models have been used to estimate the relative impact of distinct risk factors on the survival of PDAC patients. The most dramatic influence on the survival of patients diagnosed with PDAC is a surgical resection of the tumor, with less than 20% of patients suitable for surgical resection.
* A web-based, real-time prognostic tool was developed to estimate survival and conditional survival probabilities for patients with PDAC, using data from 18,352 pathologically confirmed cases of PDAC diagnosed between 2004 and 2009. The tool uses Cox proportional hazards regression models adjusted by demographic, clinical, and medical treatment covariates. The tool has been shown to have high reproducibility and generalizability, with c-index values of 0.702 and 0.712 for localized and extended PDAC cases, respectively.
</summary>

• According to WHO experts, if rubella infection occurs during early pregnancy, the potential of passing the virus through the placenta and reaching the fetus is about 90%. The most important complication of rubella is congenital rubella syndrome (CRS), which directly relates to lack of immunity during pregnancy. Rubella vaccination is crucial to prevent CRS and its complications. By vaccinating all susceptible people or women in reproductive age, it is possible to prevent the disease in mothers and their fetuses.
• The primary purpose of rubella vaccination is to prevent congenital infection with the rubella virus and CRS, which affects an estimated 110,000 infants each year in developing countries. The disease is spread globally, and before the vaccination era, its attacks were most common between February and April in countries without effective childhood vaccination policies. In closed populations, such as military camps or prisons, the possibility of infection is minimized. Rubella is usually rare in infants born from IgG-positive mothers due to antibody transfer.
• The most commonly used vaccine globally is derived from the RA27/3 virus strain, which induces more immunity compared to other vaccines. The immune response is more similar to the immunity after natural infection, and one dose induces seroconversion in 95% of vaccinated persons. A variety of seroepidemiological studies have been done globally to evaluate the situation of protective antibodies and assess the need for vaccination against the rubella virus. For example, in Australia, the rubella vaccination was established for schoolgirls since 1971, and CRS was significantly decreased thereafter.
• In Iran, a study was conducted in 2006 to evaluate and compare the susceptibility and resistance of Kermanshahi girls at marriage before and after mass rubella vaccination. The study revealed that mass vaccination caused a highly significant decrease in the rate of negative antibodies from 20.42% to 0.7%. The finding is in line with reliable sources and extensive country studies, which have compared immunity rates before and after Iranian 2003 mass vaccination. The result also agrees with research conducted in Mashhad, East of Iran.
• The effectiveness of the RA27/3 vaccine has been demonstrated by the elimination of rubella and CRS from the Western Hemisphere and by several European countries that have achieved and maintained high vaccination coverage with vaccines containing RA27/3. Mass rubella vaccination in 5-25 years old Iranian population during 2003 and continued thereafter as MMR in national vaccination programs has significantly resulted in an increase in anti-rubella

* The OECD and EPA have established guidelines for investigating thyroid toxicity in frogs, focusing on the regulation of chemicals that disrupt the thyroid axis. The guidelines use larval African clawed frogs (Xenopus laevis) and frog metamorphosis as a screening and testing method for potential endocrine disrupters.
* The histopathology of the thyroid gland is a sensitive and reliable endpoint for detecting antithyroidal activity, but it is less useful for weak agonistic effects. Well-experienced toxicologic pathologists are needed to interpret the results, as the morphology of the amphibian thyroid gland changes continuously throughout metamorphosis.
</summary>

• Cardiovascular disease (CVD) is the leading cause of death in the United States, and aspirin therapy is a recommended prevention measure to reduce the risk of major cardiovascular events. However, a study found that only a third of individuals eligible for primary prevention reported being recommended by their doctor to take aspirin.
• The study analyzed data from the National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey (NHANES) 2011-2012 and found that over three-fourths of primary-prevention patients were classified as low risk, but less than half of high-risk patients received a recommendation to take aspirin. The majority of those told to take aspirin complied with the recommendation.
• The study also found that objective risk level was not associated with an increased risk of recommendation for aspirin, suggesting that decisions for treatment recommendations are made on criteria other than objectively calculated future CVD risk. The benefit of using aspirin in low-risk patients who do not have clinical CVD is negated by the risk of harms from gastrointestinal bleeding.
• The study highlights a persistent problem with access to care and receipt of recommendations for aspirin use, with lack of health insurance being a significant barrier to accessing health care, especially for preventive services. The study also found racial and ethnic disparities in primary prevention, with non-Hispanic whites more likely to receive a recommendation for aspirin than other racial/ethnic groups.
</summary>

• The use of cell type-specific molecular markers has enabled the description and analysis of developmental morphogenesis in various biological systems. Gene-specific RNA probes are now extensively used to visualize gene expression patterns and provide valuable information regarding the role of specific genes during development. Whole mount in situ hybridization (WISH) is a widely used technique that has been simplified with the use of nonradioactive probes. This technique is commonly used in developmental research labs and has diverse applications, including medical and prenatal diagnostics.
• The use of fluorescent methods for detecting transcripts has several advantages over chromogenic methods, including higher quality three-dimensional imaging and multiplexing different RNA species. However, the high endogenous background fluorescence of many embryos and the limited brightness and photostability of organic fluorophores are major limitations. Quantum dots (QDs) have been used recently in several systems for detection of proteins and in vivo for protein labeling and lineage tracing. QDs have ideal optical properties for use in biology, including strong fluorescent signal emission and longer excited state lifetime.
• The use of QDs for in situ hybridization has several advantages, including wide excitation spectra, narrow and tunable emission spectra, and resistance to photobleaching. However, commercially available QDs are quite large and suffer from permeability problems, which can limit their use in whole-mount in situ hybridization experiments. Proteinase K treatment can render xenopus embryos sufficiently permeable to allow QD penetration deep within embryonic tissues. This treatment enables specific deep tissue staining and can be used in conjunction with QD-based in situ hybridization protocols.
• The use of QDs in in situ hybridization experiments has been shown to provide highly specific staining of dig-labeled mRNA probes, even in deep tissues. QDs can also label alternative modified oligonucleotide probes through biotin-streptavidin and FITC-anti-FITC interactions. The QD in situ protocol can be used to detect two or more transcripts simultaneously, and the resolving ability of this method is substantially better than that of amplified protocols. This is evident in high-magnification images of whole-mount-stained embryos showing the intracellular mRNA localization for xa-1 and ltbp1.
• The QD in situ protocol has several advantages over traditional in situ hybridization methods, including the ability to remain localized and fluorescent for more than an hour after the embryo is cleared. This has not been possible using traditional chromogenic or fluorescent methods. The QD in situ protocol can be used to create three-dimensional maps of expression

* Mitochondria produce reactive oxygen species (ROS) during oxidative metabolism, which can regulate signaling pathways, including those involved in tumorgenesis, immune responses, and cellular adaptation to stresses. ROS generation is required for the propagation of numerous cellular signaling pathways.
* Mitochondrial ROS (mROS) generation plays a key role in cellular differentiation programs, and increased cellular ROS levels and oxidation products correlate with the differentiation of stem cells. mROS act as pro-differentiation signals and are key upstream regulators of stem cell fate decisions.
* The identities of the exact targets of oxidation which promote signaling remain unknown in most situations, but recent studies have identified nucleoredoxin (Nxn) as a putative target of mROS-mediated Wnt-β-catenin signaling. Nxn becomes oxidized when wild-type keratinocytes are treated with the β-catenin activator Wnt-3a.
* Mitochondrial metabolism promotes cellular differentiation through various mechanisms, including the regulation of chromatin by histone acetylation and demethylation. The availability of acetyl-CoA, a key fuel for oxidative metabolism, is essential for histone acetylation and differentiation of stem cells.
</summary>

• The study recruited 278 Japanese patients with chronic limb ischemia (CLI) who underwent percutaneous transluminal angioplasty (PTA) between 2003 and 2009. The patients were evaluated for limb ischemia by angiography, and the diagnosis and management of CLI were compliant with the Transatlantic Inter-Society Consensus (TASC) II.

• The study found that diabetic patients had a higher prevalence of Fontaine stage IV and hemodialysis than non-diabetic patients. Diabetic patients also had a higher rate of major amputation compared to non-diabetic patients.

• The study analyzed the association of preoperative variables with the prognosis of CLI patients undergoing PTA. The presence of diabetes was independently associated with major amputation, and the adjusted hazard ratio (HR) was 3.101 (95% CI 1.262-7.621) (p = 0.014).

• The study also found that mortality was associated with age, impaired activities of daily living (ADLs), hemodialysis, and serum albumin level. The adjusted HRs were 1.036 (1.010-1.063) in the 1-year increment (p = 0.007) and 2.302 (1.407-3.605) (p < 0.001), 2.699 (1.682-4.332) (p < 0.001), and 1.788 (1.150-2.782) in the 1-g/dl decrement (p = 0.010), respectively.

• The study further analyzed the influence of the presence of diabetes on major amputation according to their A1C level. The two higher A1C quartiles of the diabetic group (A1C 6.8%) had a significantly higher risk than the non-diabetic group.

• The study found that diabetes with A1C 6.8%, infection, and hemodialysis were significantly associated with major amputation. The adjusted HRs were 2.907 (95% CI 1.606-5.264) (p < 0.001), 2.375 (1.198-4.711) (p = 0.014), and 3.530 (1.772-7.029) (p < 0.001), respectively.

• Human cystic echinococcosis (CE), caused by Echinococcus granulosus, is a widespread parasitic zoonosis that affects humans through accidental ingestion of infected dog feces. The disease is common in areas with close contact between intermediate and definitive hosts, usually sheep and dogs. CE presents with symptoms associated with fluid-filled cysts in the liver, lungs, or other viscera, and diagnosis is established by radiology and serology. Relapses can occur after treatment due to nonradical surgical procedures or perisurgical spillage of parasite material.

• Postsurgical follow-up of CE patients for years is necessary to detect newly growing cysts as soon as possible. A posttreatment follow-up method should include markers that allow the detection of newly growing or relapsing cysts and tracking of previously undetected but still viable cysts. Serology has been used for post-operative control of hydatidosis, but the long persistence of anti-E. granulosus antibodies after recovery makes diagnosis of relapse difficult. New immunodiagnostic tools are needed to meet the requirements expressed by clinicians.

• This study examined the pattern of antigenic bands essential for the serologic diagnosis of CE using immunoblotting analysis. Blood samples were obtained from 50 patients with CE, 40 non-CE patients, and 20 healthy controls. The sera were analyzed using Western blotting, and the results were compared between preoperative and post-operative groups. The study aimed to identify specific antigenic bands that could serve as diagnostic markers for CE.

• The study found that the antigenic bands with molecular weights of 52, 24, 39, 46, 63, and 60-61 kDa were specific for hydatid disease and had higher diagnostic value. The 39 kDa band reactivity decreased significantly after surgery, but 24 kDa and 39 kDa persisted in two patients who had a relapse at two-year follow-up. The antigenic fractions of 52, 46, 39, and 24 kDa in combination may serve as useful diagnostic markers. The study suggests that Western blotting is a useful method for diagnosing hydatidosis and for post-surgical monitoring.

• The study's results are in agreement with previous studies that have identified specific antigenic bands for CE. The antigenic bands of 24, 32-34, 44-46, and 52-54 kDa were observed in sera of patients with

<summary>
• Obesity is a common metabolic disease worldwide, often described by classical parameters such as body mass index (BMI), waist circumference (WC), and waist-to-hip ratio (WHR). Recent studies have drawn attention to new obesity indices, including waist-to-height ratio (WHTR), visceral adiposity index (VAI), and body adiposity index (BAI), which also take into account adipose tissue distribution. These new indices may be helpful for assessing risk of metabolic complications, including dyslipidemia, and predicting cardiovascular events in obese patients.
• The study aimed to examine the relationship between obesity parameters or indices (BMI, WC, WHR, WHTR, BAI, VAI) and serum lipid levels in obese non-diabetic patients. The study was conducted in a population of 66 consecutively enrolled obese non-diabetic patients, with a mean age of 55.8 years, including 40 women and 26 men. The patients were divided into three groups according to their obesity level: class I, class II, and class III obesity.
• The results showed that patients in class III obesity had greater mean WC compared to class II and class I obesity, and mean WHTR, BMI, and BAI values were higher in class III compared to class II and class I. Mean serum total cholesterol (TC) and low-density lipoprotein cholesterol (LDL-C) in class III were significantly lower than in class I. Negative significant correlations were found between BMI and TC, LDL-C, and HDL-C, and between WC, WHR, and VAI and HDL-C.
• The study found a negative correlation between BMI, WC, and LDL-C, which may be due to a lower LDL-C level in patients with morbid obesity. The authors suggest that the relationship between BMI and LDL-C serum levels is complex and depends on numerous factors such as age or sex. The study also found a positive correlation between WC and triglycerides (TG) levels and a negative correlation between WC and HDL-C levels.
• The results of the study suggest that obesity, especially abdominal obesity, is significantly associated with dyslipidemia, which manifests itself mainly with reductions in HDL-C. The VAI index demonstrated the strongest correlation with TG and HDL-C levels and with the lipid indices TC/HDL-C, LDL-C/HDL-C, and TG/HDL-C. * The study focuses on the development of epoxyeicosatrienoic acid (EET) surrogates with improved stability and efficacy as agonists for vascular relaxation and soluble epoxide hydrolase (SEH) inhibition.
* The researchers synthesized and evaluated various EET analogues, including ureas, oxamides, and heterocyclic compounds, to identify potential candidates for further development as therapeutic agents.

• The frequency response of the resonators was measured using a downmixing method, described in detail in the source document. The device was electrostatically actuated, and the driving voltage was applied to a side-gate parallel to the resonator. To reduce parasitic signals, the drive signal was set to half the actuation frequency.

• The amplitude of motion of the resonator was proportional to the square of the actuation voltage. A bias voltage at (+) through the gauges was used to down-mix their resistance change (occurring at the actuation frequency). The low-frequency readout signal at was detected using a lock-in amplifier.

• Typical measurement values were 1.5 V for the bias voltage at a measurement frequency of 500 kHz. All measurements were performed in a vacuum chamber at a pressure of 10 mbar and at room temperature. Thermomechanical noise was measured using the same set-up, with the drive electrode disconnected.

• Measurements were taken with a lock-in amplifier, which also generated the drive and bias signals. The Allan deviation was measured in open-loop configuration, and the frequency stability was extracted from the response of the resonator actuated at resonance frequency with a fixed driving frequency. The phase of the measured signal was monitored for a certain amount of time.

• The phase response of the resonator was used to transform the phase into frequency fluctuations. Close to the resonance frequency, this phase response was linear, f2qf0. Using the complete phase response of the resonator instead of this linearization does not significantly alter the Allan deviation.

• Harmonics appearing at the frequency of the electricity supply (multiples of 50 Hz) were filtered out of data during post-processing. Using this method, n samples of the resonance frequency of the resonator f1fn were obtained, each averaged over an integration time, 0. The Allan deviation for this integration time could then be defined as (2)a(0)=12(n1)1n1(fi+1fif0)2.

• Initial samples were averaged in groups of n samples, and the Allan deviation for the new array was calculated using equation (2) to determine a(n0). This process was repeated multiple times until the number of samples was too low to provide a statistically significant result. Correlation measurements were performed by simultaneously measuring the response of the resonator at different frequencies within the resonator's bandwidth.

<summary>
• The American Academy of Family Physicians, the American Academy of Pediatrics, the American College of Physicians, and the American Osteopathic Association developed the Joint Principles of the Patient-Centered Medical Home (PCMH) to improve healthcare in the United States.
• The PCMH model aims to provide quality, coordinated, and cost-effective care to patients, increase access to services, and improve practice efficiency and patient satisfaction.
• Over 1,500 sites and 7,700 clinicians across the United States have successfully completed the National Committee for Quality Assurance (NCQA) recognition process and are functioning as PCMHs.
• The transition to PCMH requires significant changes in office culture, including promoting physician buy-in, changing office culture, care coordination, staffing and space allocations, and leveraging electronic medical records (EMRs).
• The PCMH model recommends team-based care, which requires staff to address patient treatment decisions collectively, and encourages practices to use registries and care coordinators to focus on patients with chronic conditions.
• The PCMH model holds great potential in addressing the broken healthcare system in the United States, but faces many obstacles in terms of payment reform, professional support, and patient participation.
</summary>

* The hepatitis C virus (HCV) is a single-stranded RNA virus belonging to the Flaviviridae family. HCV study has progressed mainly in the field of functional analysis and therapeutic implications. Due to low viral levels in the serum, diagnosis of HCV infection has been made using branched chain DNA signal amplification assay and reverse-transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR).
* The detection of HCV in human liver tissue has been reported using immunohistochemistry and in situ hybridization (ISH). However, these methods are not yet reproducible enough. * The study also included 11 needle biopsy liver specimens of chronic hepatitis C, which were FFPE and cut into sections. In addition, needle biopsy specimens of hepatitis-B-virus (HBV)-infected chronic hepatitis, virus-negative fatty liver, and autoimmune hepatitis were examined. Two surgically removed HCC lesions caused by HCV or HBV infection were also evaluated.
* The activity of inflammation and the degree of fibrosis were evaluated according to the new Inuyama classification (1996). Serum HCV-RNA levels in the patients were measured using an RT-PCR assay, and serum HCV subtypes were determined with nested RT-PCR. The sequence of an HCV-common probe was designed according to the previous description.
* The target was within the HCV 5'-untranslated region (HCV-5'UTR), which is a highly conserved portion in the HCV genome. An LNA-modified oligonucleotide probe labeled with digoxygenin at the 3-end was prepared. The nucleotide sequence of the 45-mer probe was 5'-altttlggglcgtlgcclccclgcglagalctglctalgcclgagltagltgtltgglgt-3.

* A study involving 66,726 patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) found that insulin analogues, such as biphasic insulin aspart, basal + insulin aspart, insulin detemir, and insulin aspart, improved glycaemic control and quality of life after 24 weeks of treatment.
* The study reported a significant reduction in hypoglycaemic events, with no major hypoglycaemic events or episodes occurring in any of the study patients, and improved lipid profiles and blood pressure.
* The findings suggest that insulin analogues can be considered effective and possess a safe profile for treating T2DM, although the study notes that body weight increased in the insulin-naive group while remaining unchanged in the insulin-user group.
</summary>

* A male factor is recognized in approximately 40% of marital infertility cases, with varicocele being a significant contributor.
* Varicocele is characterized by persistent enlargement and elongation of the pampiniform plexus, venous convolution, and sinus formation with transient or permanent backflow.
* The etiology of varicocele remains unclear, but it is believed to be related to blood turbulence and retrograde flow of renal metabolites and adrenal hormones to the testis.
* Laparoscopic varicocele repair is a recommended treatment for varicocele, particularly in adolescents, as it can improve testicular volume and semen parameters.
* The study found that laparoscopic varicocele repair resulted in a significant increase in hypotrophic testicular volume in 83.8% of patients.
* Semen analysis revealed normozoospermia in 85.2% of patients, while 14.7% had oligozoospermia, asthenozoospermia, or teratozoospermia.
* Varicocele recurrence was observed in only 2.9% of patients, and complications developed in 8.8% of patients, including hydrocele testis and epididymitis.
* The study suggests that laparoscopic varicocele repair should be recommended as the treatment of choice for varicocele, particularly in adolescents.
* Postoperative follow-up of young men after they turn 18 facilitates objective evaluation of the efficacy of surgical varicocele repair and assessment of hormonal tests and semen analysis.
</summary>

• Cesarean sections (CS) performed without medical indication may contribute to higher rates of CS worldwide. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends a 10-15% rate of CS, but many countries have rates far higher than this. The rate of CS in Iran has increased six-fold over the past three decades. This increase is consistent with previous reports of growing CS rates in Iran.

• The debate on the best practices for minimizing postnatal morbidity is ongoing, with some studies suggesting that vaginal delivery (VD) may be associated with better health outcomes. However, other studies have found no significant differences between VD and CS. The mode of delivery may have a long-term effect on self-rated health. Several studies have investigated the association between type of delivery and health-related quality of life (HRQOL).

• A prospective study was conducted in Iran to explore the impact of delivery mode on women's postpartum physical and mental health-related quality of life (HRQOL). The study included 365 consecutive women who agreed to participate and completed HRQOL questionnaires at 2 and 4 months after delivery. The study found that physical HRQOL at 2 and 4 months after delivery was better in women with VD. The study also found that mental HRQOL at 4 months after delivery was better in VD group.

• The study compared the physical and mental health parameters related to HRQOL at 2 and 4 months after delivery between women with VD and CS. The results showed that total physical health score in VD women was higher than in CS group at 2 months after delivery. The study also found that total mental health score in CS women was generally higher than in VD group, but differences were not significant. The study found that the VD group had a higher score in total physical health and total mental health at 4 months postpartum.

• The study found that the VD group showed more improvements on total mental HRQOL from time 1 to time 2 assessment. The mean score differences in VD and CS groups were 4.70 and 0.3, respectively, with a significant difference between the two groups. The study also found that the VD group had a higher score in physical function and emotional well-being at 4 months after delivery. The study's results are consistent with several previous studies that found better HRQOL outcomes in women who had VD.

<summary>

• Maslow's hierarchy of needs has been a well-known theory since 1943, proposing that human needs can be portrayed in a pyramid with the most fundamental levels at the bottom. Physiological needs are the physical requirements for survival, such as food and sex, while safety needs are personal security, financial security, and health and well-being. Maslow proposed that if physiological needs are relatively satisfied, safety needs emerge, and the organism may be dominated by them. Safety needs are more fundamental than physiological needs, as seen in the example of a deer that cannot eat on the wild prairie when wolves chase it.

• Maslow's theory is supported by the work of Cosmides and Tooby, who propose that emotions serve to regulate behavior. Fear, for example, is an emotion that serves to regulate behavior in response to potential threats. The example of walking alone at night and hearing rustling in the brush illustrates how fear can prepare the body for action. This fear response is automatic and can override other needs, such as physiological needs.

• The safety needs can block physiological needs, as seen in Miller's avoidance and approach experiments. In these experiments, animals were more sensitive to threatening information and processed it faster than rewarding information. This phenomenon is known as negativity bias and is attributed to a protective strategy through evolution. Negativity bias can be seen across all levels of the neural organization.

• Maslow used infants as an example to illustrate the safety needs, as they prefer a predictable and orderly world. Injustice or inconsistency in the parents can make a child feel anxious and unsafe. This attitude is not due to the injustices themselves but because they threaten to make the world look unreliable or unsafe. Confronting new or unfamiliar stimuli can elicit danger or terror reactions in children.

• The appraisal theory, proposed by Magda Arnold and Richard Lazarus, states that emotions result from people's interpretations and explanations of their circumstances. Primary appraisal is a faster, automatic process that involves evaluating the threat or harm of a situation. Secondary appraisal is concerned with coping options, such as blame or credit, coping potential, and future expectations. The primary appraisal is related to fear, while the secondary appraisal is related to anger.

• The amygdala is the neural basis for fear and is also recognized as the neural basis for stress-elicited fear and anxiety. Electrical stimulation of the amygdala promotes autonomous reactions and stress-like behavior, while amygdala ablation reduces fear and anxiety. The amygdala is linked to the ne/lc system

* Over the past decade, various cell types have been studied for cardiac regeneration, including embryonic stem cells, mesenchymal stem cells, skeletal myoblasts, and bone marrow-derived progenitor cells.
* Induced pluripotent stem cells (iPSCs) have emerged as a promising alternative, offering an unlimited supply of autologous donor cells with reduced risks of teratoma formation and graft-versus-host disease.
* Mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs) can differentiate into cardiomyocytes under special conditions, but their propensity to differentiate into non-cardiac tissues limits their use.
* Bone marrow-derived mononuclear cells have shown improved ventricular function and reduced infarct scar size in clinical trials, but the optimal method of delivery and timing of administration remains a challenge.
* Cell-based gene therapy, including the use of survival factors such as Akt-1, Bcl-2, and SFRP2, has shown promise in enhancing donor cell survival and promoting myocardial repair.
* Recent studies have identified committed cardiac progenitor cells in the adult heart, which can be isolated and differentiated into functional cardiomyocytes, offering a potential alternative to embryonic stem cells and iPSCs.</summary>

• Radical retropubic prostatectomy is the surgical treatment of choice for patients with localized prostate cancer, but the major long-term morbidity is erectile dysfunction, despite advances in surgical techniques. Prior to studies by Walsh and Donker, the cause of erectile dysfunction after radical prostatectomy was not well understood. They proposed that erectile dysfunction occurred secondary to the injury of cavernosal nerves.
• Nerve-sparing radical retropubic prostatectomy has led to improvements in potency rates, with studies reporting a 16 to 76% recovery of erectile function in men whose bilateral neurovascular bundles were preserved. However, the variability in potency rates can be attributed to the fact that there was no definite and exact anatomy of periprostatic nerve fibers. The anatomy of periprostatic nerves is still a topic of controversy in the literature.
• A recent study described the periprostatic nerve distribution and constructed a 3-dimensional model of nerve distribution using adult male human cadavers. The study found that the number of periprostatic nerve fibers was distributed evenly to dorsal and both lateral areas of the prostate. The distances from the prostatic capsule were almost the same in both the lateral and dorsal parts of the base, middle, and apex levels of the prostate.
• The study also found that the nerve fibers in the ventral part were substantially fewer in number and decreased in thickness compared to the dorsal and lateral parts. The traditional knowledge of the neurovascular bundle has been challenged, and recent descriptions have shown variations in the distributions of autonomic fibers between different individuals. The study's findings will serve as a guide for improved results for nerve-sparing radical prostatectomy.
• The study's results suggest that modified nerve-sparing techniques by incising the periprostatic fascia more anteriorly are feasible for saving periprostatic nerves. However, an excessive high-up incision over 2, 10 o'clock on the ventral part of the prostate is insignificant during nerve-sparing radical prostatectomy. The study's findings are different from previous reports, and the results have implications for the development of new surgical techniques for nerve-sparing radical prostatectomy.
</summary>

• The survival rate of cardiac arrest outside of the hospital remained 78% in the early 21st century, and about one-quarter of patients regained pulses after CPR, with about one-third of those patients surviving hospitalization. The severe brain defect after CPR stimulated many investigations into the pathophysiology of global brain ischemia.

• Mild hypothermia therapy has been proposed for the protection of patients' brains, and it has been shown to increase the survival rate and improve neurological function in animal experiments. In clinical trials, the effectiveness of hypothermia has also been proved.

• The American Heart Association guidelines for cardiopulmonary resuscitation and emergency cardiovascular care recommended cooling comatose patients with out-of-hospital ventricular fibrillation cardiac arrest to 32-34°C for 12 or 24 hours. However, recent years have shown that mild hypothermia may not improve the prognosis of patients after CPR.

• A meta-analysis was conducted to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of mild hypothermia on patients with cardiac arrest. The study included six randomized controlled trials with 531 adult patients who suffered from cardiac arrest and were successfully resuscitated.

• The meta-analysis showed that mild hypothermia did not improve the survival rate at hospital discharge, but it did improve the survival rate after 6 months. The pooled results showed that hypothermia improved the survival rate (RR = 1.25, 95% CI: 1.05-1.49, p = 0.01).

• The neurological function of patients who suffered from cardiac arrest and were successfully resuscitated was also evaluated. The meta-analysis showed that mild hypothermia did not improve the neurological function at hospital discharge, but it did improve the neurological function after 6 months.

• The incidence of rearrest was also evaluated, and the meta-analysis showed that mild hypothermia did not influence the incidence of rearrest (RR = 1.19, 95% CI: 0.87-1.61, p = 0.27). Other adverse events such as pulmonary edema, pneumonia, and bleeding were also evaluated, but the results were not significant.

• The funnel plot showed that most studies were at the top, indicating that the studies had narrow CIs and high precision. A sensitivity analysis was performed by omitting two high-risk studies, and the results showed that the pooled RR ranged from 1.25 to 1.21 for survival rate and from 1.37 to 1.30
